speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: ACT I

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: SCENE I. London. A street.

speaker: HENRY BOLINGBROKE
text_entry: Enter GLOUCESTER, solus

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Now is the winter of our discontent

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Made glorious summer by this sun of York;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And all the clouds that lour'd upon our house

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: In the deep bosom of the ocean buried.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Now are our brows bound with victorious wreaths;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Our bruised arms hung up for monuments;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Our stern alarums changed to merry meetings,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Our dreadful marches to delightful measures.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Grim-visaged war hath smooth'd his wrinkled front;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And now, instead of mounting barded steeds

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To fright the souls of fearful adversaries,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: He capers nimbly in a lady's chamber

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To the lascivious pleasing of a lute.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: But I, that am not shaped for sportive tricks,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Nor made to court an amorous looking-glass;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I, that am rudely stamp'd, and want love's majesty

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To strut before a wanton ambling nymph;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I, that am curtail'd of this fair proportion,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Cheated of feature by dissembling nature,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Deformed, unfinish'd, sent before my time

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Into this breathing world, scarce half made up,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And that so lamely and unfashionable

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: That dogs bark at me as I halt by them;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Why, I, in this weak piping time of peace,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Have no delight to pass away the time,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Unless to spy my shadow in the sun

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And descant on mine own deformity:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And therefore, since I cannot prove a lover,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To entertain these fair well-spoken days,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I am determined to prove a villain

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And hate the idle pleasures of these days.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Plots have I laid, inductions dangerous,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: By drunken prophecies, libels and dreams,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To set my brother Clarence and the king

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: In deadly hate the one against the other:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And if King Edward be as true and just

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: As I am subtle, false and treacherous,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: This day should Clarence closely be mew'd up,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: About a prophecy, which says that 'G'

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Of Edward's heirs the murderer shall be.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Dive, thoughts, down to my soul: here

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Clarence comes.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Enter CLARENCE, guarded, and BRAKENBURY

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Brother, good day; what means this armed guard

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: That waits upon your grace?

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: His majesty

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Tendering my person's safety, hath appointed

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: This conduct to convey me to the Tower.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Upon what cause?

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Because my name is George.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Alack, my lord, that fault is none of yours;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: He should, for that, commit your godfathers:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: O, belike his majesty hath some intent

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: That you shall be new-christen'd in the Tower.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: But what's the matter, Clarence?  may I know?

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Yea, Richard, when I know; for I protest

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: As yet I do not: but, as I can learn,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: He hearkens after prophecies and dreams;

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: And from the cross-row plucks the letter G.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: And says a wizard told him that by G

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: His issue disinherited should be;

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: And, for my name of George begins with G,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: It follows in his thought that I am he.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: These, as I learn, and such like toys as these

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Have moved his highness to commit me now.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Why, this it is, when men are ruled by women:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: 'Tis not the king that sends you to the Tower:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: My Lady Grey his wife, Clarence, 'tis she

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: That tempers him to this extremity.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Was it not she and that good man of worship,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Anthony Woodville, her brother there,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: That made him send Lord Hastings to the Tower,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: From whence this present day he is deliver'd?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: We are not safe, Clarence; we are not safe.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: By heaven, I think there's no man is secure

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: But the queen's kindred and night-walking heralds

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: That trudge betwixt the king and Mistress Shore.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Heard ye not what an humble suppliant

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Lord hastings was to her for his delivery?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Humbly complaining to her deity

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Got my lord chamberlain his liberty.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I'll tell you what; I think it is our way,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: If we will keep in favour with the king,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To be her men and wear her livery:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: The jealous o'erworn widow and herself,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Since that our brother dubb'd them gentlewomen.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Are mighty gossips in this monarchy.

speaker: BRAKENBURY
text_entry: I beseech your graces both to pardon me;

speaker: BRAKENBURY
text_entry: His majesty hath straitly given in charge

speaker: BRAKENBURY
text_entry: That no man shall have private conference,

speaker: BRAKENBURY
text_entry: Of what degree soever, with his brother.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Even so; an't please your worship, Brakenbury,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: You may partake of any thing we say:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: We speak no treason, man: we say the king

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Is wise and virtuous, and his noble queen

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Well struck in years, fair, and not jealous;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: We say that Shore's wife hath a pretty foot,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: A cherry lip, a bonny eye, a passing pleasing tongue;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And that the queen's kindred are made gentle-folks:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: How say you sir? Can you deny all this?

speaker: BRAKENBURY
text_entry: With this, my lord, myself have nought to do.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Naught to do with mistress Shore! I tell thee, fellow,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: He that doth naught with her, excepting one,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Were best he do it secretly, alone.

speaker: BRAKENBURY
text_entry: What one, my lord?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Her husband, knave: wouldst thou betray me?

speaker: BRAKENBURY
text_entry: I beseech your grace to pardon me, and withal

speaker: BRAKENBURY
text_entry: Forbear your conference with the noble duke.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: We know thy charge, Brakenbury, and will obey.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: We are the queen's abjects, and must obey.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Brother, farewell: I will unto the king;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And whatsoever you will employ me in,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Were it to call King Edward's widow sister,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I will perform it to enfranchise you.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Meantime, this deep disgrace in brotherhood

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Touches me deeper than you can imagine.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: I know it pleaseth neither of us well.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Well, your imprisonment shall not be long;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Meantime, have patience.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: I must perforce. Farewell.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Exeunt CLARENCE, BRAKENBURY, and Guard

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Go, tread the path that thou shalt ne'er return.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Simple, plain Clarence! I do love thee so,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: That I will shortly send thy soul to heaven,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: If heaven will take the present at our hands.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: But who comes here? the new-deliver'd Hastings?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Enter HASTINGS

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Good time of day unto my gracious lord!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: As much unto my good lord chamberlain!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Well are you welcome to the open air.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: How hath your lordship brook'd imprisonment?

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: With patience, noble lord, as prisoners must:

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: But I shall live, my lord, to give them thanks

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: That were the cause of my imprisonment.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: No doubt, no doubt; and so shall Clarence too;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: For they that were your enemies are his,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And have prevail'd as much on him as you.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: More pity that the eagle should be mew'd,

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: While kites and buzzards prey at liberty.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: What news abroad?

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: No news so bad abroad as this at home;

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: The King is sickly, weak and melancholy,

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: And his physicians fear him mightily.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Now, by Saint Paul, this news is bad indeed.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: O, he hath kept an evil diet long,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And overmuch consumed his royal person:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: 'Tis very grievous to be thought upon.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: What, is he in his bed?

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: He is.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Go you before, and I will follow you.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Exit HASTINGS

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: He cannot live, I hope; and must not die

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Till George be pack'd with post-horse up to heaven.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I'll in, to urge his hatred more to Clarence,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: With lies well steel'd with weighty arguments;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And, if I fall not in my deep intent,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Clarence hath not another day to live:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Which done, God take King Edward to his mercy,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And leave the world for me to bustle in!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: For then I'll marry Warwick's youngest daughter.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: What though I kill'd her husband and her father?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: The readiest way to make the wench amends

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Is to become her husband and her father:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: The which will I; not all so much for love

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: As for another secret close intent,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: By marrying her which I must reach unto.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: But yet I run before my horse to market:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Clarence still breathes; Edward still lives and reigns:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: When they are gone, then must I count my gains.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Exit

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: SCENE II. The same. Another street.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Enter the corpse of KING HENRY the Sixth, Gentlemen with halberds to guard it; LADY ANNE being the mourner

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Set down, set down your honourable load,

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: If honour may be shrouded in a hearse,

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Whilst I awhile obsequiously lament

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: The untimely fall of virtuous Lancaster.

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Poor key-cold figure of a holy king!

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Pale ashes of the house of Lancaster!

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Thou bloodless remnant of that royal blood!

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Be it lawful that I invocate thy ghost,

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: To hear the lamentations of Poor Anne,

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Wife to thy Edward, to thy slaughter'd son,

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Stabb'd by the selfsame hand that made these wounds!

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Lo, in these windows that let forth thy life,

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: I pour the helpless balm of my poor eyes.

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Cursed be the hand that made these fatal holes!

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Cursed be the heart that had the heart to do it!

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Cursed the blood that let this blood from hence!

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: More direful hap betide that hated wretch,

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: That makes us wretched by the death of thee,

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Than I can wish to adders, spiders, toads,

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Or any creeping venom'd thing that lives!

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: If ever he have child, abortive be it,

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Prodigious, and untimely brought to light,

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Whose ugly and unnatural aspect

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: May fright the hopeful mother at the view;

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: And that be heir to his unhappiness!

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: If ever he have wife, let her he made

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: A miserable by the death of him

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: As I am made by my poor lord and thee!

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Come, now towards Chertsey with your holy load,

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Taken from Paul's to be interred there;

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: And still, as you are weary of the weight,

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Rest you, whiles I lament King Henry's corse.

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Enter GLOUCESTER

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Stay, you that bear the corse, and set it down.

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: What black magician conjures up this fiend,

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: To stop devoted charitable deeds?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Villains, set down the corse; or, by Saint Paul,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I'll make a corse of him that disobeys.

speaker: Gentleman
text_entry: My lord, stand back, and let the coffin pass.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Unmanner'd dog! stand thou, when I command:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Advance thy halbert higher than my breast,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Or, by Saint Paul, I'll strike thee to my foot,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And spurn upon thee, beggar, for thy boldness.

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: What, do you tremble? are you all afraid?

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Alas, I blame you not; for you are mortal,

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: And mortal eyes cannot endure the devil.

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Avaunt, thou dreadful minister of hell!

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Thou hadst but power over his mortal body,

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: His soul thou canst not have; therefore be gone.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Sweet saint, for charity, be not so curst.

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Foul devil, for God's sake, hence, and trouble us not;

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: For thou hast made the happy earth thy hell,

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Fill'd it with cursing cries and deep exclaims.

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: If thou delight to view thy heinous deeds,

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Behold this pattern of thy butcheries.

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: O, gentlemen, see, see! dead Henry's wounds

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Open their congeal'd mouths and bleed afresh!

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Blush, Blush, thou lump of foul deformity;

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: For 'tis thy presence that exhales this blood

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: From cold and empty veins, where no blood dwells;

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Thy deed, inhuman and unnatural,

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Provokes this deluge most unnatural.

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: O God, which this blood madest, revenge his death!

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: O earth, which this blood drink'st revenge his death!

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Either heaven with lightning strike the

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: murderer dead,

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Or earth, gape open wide and eat him quick,

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: As thou dost swallow up this good king's blood

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Which his hell-govern'd arm hath butchered!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Lady, you know no rules of charity,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Which renders good for bad, blessings for curses.

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Villain, thou know'st no law of God nor man:

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: No beast so fierce but knows some touch of pity.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: But I know none, and therefore am no beast.

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: O wonderful, when devils tell the truth!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: More wonderful, when angels are so angry.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Vouchsafe, divine perfection of a woman,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Of these supposed-evils, to give me leave,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: By circumstance, but to acquit myself.

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Vouchsafe, defused infection of a man,

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: For these known evils, but to give me leave,

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: By circumstance, to curse thy cursed self.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Fairer than tongue can name thee, let me have

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Some patient leisure to excuse myself.

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Fouler than heart can think thee, thou canst make

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: No excuse current, but to hang thyself.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: By such despair, I should accuse myself.

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: And, by despairing, shouldst thou stand excused;

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: For doing worthy vengeance on thyself,

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Which didst unworthy slaughter upon others.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Say that I slew them not?

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Why, then they are not dead:

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: But dead they are, and devilish slave, by thee.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I did not kill your husband.

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Why, then he is alive.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Nay, he is dead; and slain by Edward's hand.

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: In thy foul throat thou liest: Queen Margaret saw

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Thy murderous falchion smoking in his blood;

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: The which thou once didst bend against her breast,

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: But that thy brothers beat aside the point.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I was provoked by her slanderous tongue,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: which laid their guilt upon my guiltless shoulders.

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Thou wast provoked by thy bloody mind.

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Which never dreamt on aught but butcheries:

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Didst thou not kill this king?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I grant ye.

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Dost grant me, hedgehog? then, God grant me too

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Thou mayst be damned for that wicked deed!

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: O, he was gentle, mild, and virtuous!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: The fitter for the King of heaven, that hath him.

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: He is in heaven, where thou shalt never come.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Let him thank me, that holp to send him thither;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: For he was fitter for that place than earth.

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: And thou unfit for any place but hell.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Yes, one place else, if you will hear me name it.

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Some dungeon.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Your bed-chamber.

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: I'll rest betide the chamber where thou liest!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: So will it, madam till I lie with you.

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: I hope so.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I know so. But, gentle Lady Anne,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To leave this keen encounter of our wits,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And fall somewhat into a slower method,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Is not the causer of the timeless deaths

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Of these Plantagenets, Henry and Edward,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: As blameful as the executioner?

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Thou art the cause, and most accursed effect.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Your beauty was the cause of that effect;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Your beauty: which did haunt me in my sleep

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To undertake the death of all the world,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: So I might live one hour in your sweet bosom.

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: If I thought that, I tell thee, homicide,

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: These nails should rend that beauty from my cheeks.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: These eyes could never endure sweet beauty's wreck;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: You should not blemish it, if I stood by:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: As all the world is cheered by the sun,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: So I by that; it is my day, my life.

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Black night o'ershade thy day, and death thy life!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Curse not thyself, fair creature thou art both.

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: I would I were, to be revenged on thee.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: It is a quarrel most unnatural,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To be revenged on him that loveth you.

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: It is a quarrel just and reasonable,

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: To be revenged on him that slew my husband.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: He that bereft thee, lady, of thy husband,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Did it to help thee to a better husband.

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: His better doth not breathe upon the earth.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: He lives that loves thee better than he could.

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Name him.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Plantagenet.

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Why, that was he.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: The selfsame name, but one of better nature.

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Where is he?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Here.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: She spitteth at him

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Why dost thou spit at me?

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Would it were mortal poison, for thy sake!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Never came poison from so sweet a place.

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Never hung poison on a fouler toad.

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Out of my sight! thou dost infect my eyes.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Thine eyes, sweet lady, have infected mine.

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Would they were basilisks, to strike thee dead!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I would they were, that I might die at once;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: For now they kill me with a living death.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Those eyes of thine from mine have drawn salt tears,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Shamed their aspect with store of childish drops:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: These eyes that never shed remorseful tear,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: No, when my father York and Edward wept,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To hear the piteous moan that Rutland made

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: When black-faced Clifford shook his sword at him;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Nor when thy warlike father, like a child,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Told the sad story of my father's death,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And twenty times made pause to sob and weep,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: That all the standers-by had wet their cheeks

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Like trees bedash'd with rain: in that sad time

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: My manly eyes did scorn an humble tear;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And what these sorrows could not thence exhale,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Thy beauty hath, and made them blind with weeping.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I never sued to friend nor enemy;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: My tongue could never learn sweet smoothing word;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: But now thy beauty is proposed my fee,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: My proud heart sues, and prompts my tongue to speak.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: She looks scornfully at him

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Teach not thy lips such scorn, for they were made

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: For kissing, lady, not for such contempt.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: If thy revengeful heart cannot forgive,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Lo, here I lend thee this sharp-pointed sword;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Which if thou please to hide in this true bosom.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And let the soul forth that adoreth thee,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I lay it naked to the deadly stroke,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And humbly beg the death upon my knee.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: He lays his breast open: she offers at it with his sword

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Nay, do not pause; for I did kill King Henry,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: But 'twas thy beauty that provoked me.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Nay, now dispatch; 'twas I that stabb'd young Edward,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: But 'twas thy heavenly face that set me on.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Here she lets fall the sword

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Take up the sword again, or take up me.

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Arise, dissembler: though I wish thy death,

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: I will not be the executioner.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Then bid me kill myself, and I will do it.

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: I have already.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Tush, that was in thy rage:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Speak it again, and, even with the word,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: That hand, which, for thy love, did kill thy love,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Shall, for thy love, kill a far truer love;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To both their deaths thou shalt be accessary.

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: I would I knew thy heart.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: 'Tis figured in my tongue.

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: I fear me both are false.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Then never man was true.

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Well, well, put up your sword.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Say, then, my peace is made.

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: That shall you know hereafter.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: But shall I live in hope?

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: All men, I hope, live so.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Vouchsafe to wear this ring.

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: To take is not to give.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Look, how this ring encompasseth finger.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Even so thy breast encloseth my poor heart;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Wear both of them, for both of them are thine.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And if thy poor devoted suppliant may

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: But beg one favour at thy gracious hand,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Thou dost confirm his happiness for ever.

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: What is it?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: That it would please thee leave these sad designs

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To him that hath more cause to be a mourner,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And presently repair to Crosby Place;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Where, after I have solemnly interr'd

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: At Chertsey monastery this noble king,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And wet his grave with my repentant tears,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I will with all expedient duty see you:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: For divers unknown reasons. I beseech you,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Grant me this boon.

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: With all my heart; and much it joys me too,

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: To see you are become so penitent.

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Tressel and Berkeley, go along with me.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Bid me farewell.

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: 'Tis more than you deserve;

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: But since you teach me how to flatter you,

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Imagine I have said farewell already.

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Exeunt LADY ANNE, TRESSEL, and BERKELEY

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Sirs, take up the corse.

speaker: GENTLEMEN
text_entry: Towards Chertsey, noble lord?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: No, to White-Friars; there attend my coining.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Exeunt all but GLOUCESTER

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Was ever woman in this humour woo'd?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Was ever woman in this humour won?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I'll have her; but I will not keep her long.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: What! I, that kill'd her husband and his father,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To take her in her heart's extremest hate,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: With curses in her mouth, tears in her eyes,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: The bleeding witness of her hatred by;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Having God, her conscience, and these bars

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: against me,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And I nothing to back my suit at all,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: But the plain devil and dissembling looks,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And yet to win her, all the world to nothing!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Ha!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Hath she forgot already that brave prince,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Edward, her lord, whom I, some three months since,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Stabb'd in my angry mood at Tewksbury?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: A sweeter and a lovelier gentleman,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Framed in the prodigality of nature,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Young, valiant, wise, and, no doubt, right royal,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: The spacious world cannot again afford

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And will she yet debase her eyes on me,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: That cropp'd the golden prime of this sweet prince,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And made her widow to a woful bed?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: On me, whose all not equals Edward's moiety?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: On me, that halt and am unshapen thus?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: My dukedom to a beggarly denier,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I do mistake my person all this while:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Upon my life, she finds, although I cannot,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Myself to be a marvellous proper man.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I'll be at charges for a looking-glass,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And entertain some score or two of tailors,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To study fashions to adorn my body:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Since I am crept in favour with myself,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Will maintain it with some little cost.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: But first I'll turn yon fellow in his grave;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And then return lamenting to my love.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Shine out, fair sun, till I have bought a glass,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: That I may see my shadow as I pass.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Exit

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: SCENE III. The palace.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Enter QUEEN ELIZABETH, RIVERS, and GREY

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: Have patience, madam: there's no doubt his majesty

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: Will soon recover his accustom'd health.

speaker: GREY
text_entry: In that you brook it in, it makes him worse:

speaker: GREY
text_entry: Therefore, for God's sake, entertain good comfort,

speaker: GREY
text_entry: And cheer his grace with quick and merry words.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: If he were dead, what would betide of me?

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: No other harm but loss of such a lord.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: The loss of such a lord includes all harm.

speaker: GREY
text_entry: The heavens have bless'd you with a goodly son,

speaker: GREY
text_entry: To be your comforter when he is gone.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Oh, he is young and his minority

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Is put unto the trust of Richard Gloucester,

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: A man that loves not me, nor none of you.

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: Is it concluded that he shall be protector?

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: It is determined, not concluded yet:

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: But so it must be, if the king miscarry.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Enter BUCKINGHAM and DERBY

speaker: GREY
text_entry: Here come the lords of Buckingham and Derby.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Good time of day unto your royal grace!

speaker: DERBY
text_entry: God make your majesty joyful as you have been!

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: The Countess Richmond, good my Lord of Derby.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: To your good prayers will scarcely say amen.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Yet, Derby, notwithstanding she's your wife,

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: And loves not me, be you, good lord, assured

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: I hate not you for her proud arrogance.

speaker: DERBY
text_entry: I do beseech you, either not believe

speaker: DERBY
text_entry: The envious slanders of her false accusers;

speaker: DERBY
text_entry: Or, if she be accused in true report,

speaker: DERBY
text_entry: Bear with her weakness, which, I think proceeds

speaker: DERBY
text_entry: From wayward sickness, and no grounded malice.

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: Saw you the king to-day, my Lord of Derby?

speaker: DERBY
text_entry: But now the Duke of Buckingham and I

speaker: DERBY
text_entry: Are come from visiting his majesty.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: What likelihood of his amendment, lords?

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Madam, good hope; his grace speaks cheerfully.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: God grant him health! Did you confer with him?

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Madam, we did: he desires to make atonement

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Betwixt the Duke of Gloucester and your brothers,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: And betwixt them and my lord chamberlain;

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: And sent to warn them to his royal presence.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Would all were well! but that will never be

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: I fear our happiness is at the highest.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Enter GLOUCESTER, HASTINGS, and DORSET

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: They do me wrong, and I will not endure it:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Who are they that complain unto the king,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: That I, forsooth, am stern, and love them not?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: By holy Paul, they love his grace but lightly

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: That fill his ears with such dissentious rumours.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Because I cannot flatter and speak fair,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Smile in men's faces, smooth, deceive and cog,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Duck with French nods and apish courtesy,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I must be held a rancorous enemy.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Cannot a plain man live and think no harm,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: But thus his simple truth must be abused

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: By silken, sly, insinuating Jacks?

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: To whom in all this presence speaks your grace?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To thee, that hast nor honesty nor grace.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: When have I injured thee? when done thee wrong?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Or thee? or thee? or any of your faction?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: A plague upon you all! His royal person,--

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Whom God preserve better than you would wish!--

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Cannot be quiet scarce a breathing-while,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: But you must trouble him with lewd complaints.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Brother of Gloucester, you mistake the matter.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: The king, of his own royal disposition,

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: And not provoked by any suitor else;

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Aiming, belike, at your interior hatred,

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Which in your outward actions shows itself

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Against my kindred, brothers, and myself,

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Makes him to send; that thereby he may gather

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: The ground of your ill-will, and so remove it.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I cannot tell: the world is grown so bad,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: That wrens make prey where eagles dare not perch:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Since every Jack became a gentleman

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: There's many a gentle person made a Jack.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Come, come, we know your meaning, brother

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Gloucester;

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: You envy my advancement and my friends':

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: God grant we never may have need of you!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Meantime, God grants that we have need of you:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Your brother is imprison'd by your means,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Myself disgraced, and the nobility

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Held in contempt; whilst many fair promotions

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Are daily given to ennoble those

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: That scarce, some two days since, were worth a noble.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: By Him that raised me to this careful height

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: From that contented hap which I enjoy'd,

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: I never did incense his majesty

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Against the Duke of Clarence, but have been

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: An earnest advocate to plead for him.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: My lord, you do me shameful injury,

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Falsely to draw me in these vile suspects.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: You may deny that you were not the cause

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Of my Lord Hastings' late imprisonment.

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: She may, my lord, for--

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: She may, Lord Rivers! why, who knows not so?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: She may do more, sir, than denying that:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: She may help you to many fair preferments,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And then deny her aiding hand therein,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And lay those honours on your high deserts.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: What may she not? She may, yea, marry, may she--

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: What, marry, may she?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: What, marry, may she! marry with a king,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: A bachelor, a handsome stripling too:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I wis your grandam had a worser match.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: My Lord of Gloucester, I have too long borne

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Your blunt upbraidings and your bitter scoffs:

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: By heaven, I will acquaint his majesty

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: With those gross taunts I often have endured.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: I had rather be a country servant-maid

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Than a great queen, with this condition,

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: To be thus taunted, scorn'd, and baited at:

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Enter QUEEN MARGARET, behind

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Small joy have I in being England's queen.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And lessen'd be that small, God, I beseech thee!

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Thy honour, state and seat is due to me.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: What! threat you me with telling of the king?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Tell him, and spare not: look, what I have said

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I will avouch in presence of the king:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I dare adventure to be sent to the Tower.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: 'Tis time to speak; my pains are quite forgot.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Out, devil! I remember them too well:

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Thou slewest my husband Henry in the Tower,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And Edward, my poor son, at Tewksbury.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Ere you were queen, yea, or your husband king,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I was a pack-horse in his great affairs;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: A weeder-out of his proud adversaries,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: A liberal rewarder of his friends:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To royalize his blood I spilt mine own.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Yea, and much better blood than his or thine.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: In all which time you and your husband Grey

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Were factious for the house of Lancaster;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And, Rivers, so were you. Was not your husband

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: In Margaret's battle at Saint Alban's slain?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Let me put in your minds, if you forget,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: What you have been ere now, and what you are;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Withal, what I have been, and what I am.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: A murderous villain, and so still thou art.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Poor Clarence did forsake his father, Warwick;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Yea, and forswore himself,--which Jesu pardon!--

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Which God revenge!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To fight on Edward's party for the crown;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And for his meed, poor lord, he is mew'd up.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I would to God my heart were flint, like Edward's;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Or Edward's soft and pitiful, like mine

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I am too childish-foolish for this world.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Hie thee to hell for shame, and leave the world,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Thou cacodemon! there thy kingdom is.

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: My Lord of Gloucester, in those busy days

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: Which here you urge to prove us enemies,

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: We follow'd then our lord, our lawful king:

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: So should we you, if you should be our king.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: If I should be! I had rather be a pedlar:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Far be it from my heart, the thought of it!

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: As little joy, my lord, as you suppose

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: You should enjoy, were you this country's king,

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: As little joy may you suppose in me.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: That I enjoy, being the queen thereof.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: A little joy enjoys the queen thereof;

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: For I am she, and altogether joyless.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: I can no longer hold me patient.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Advancing

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Hear me, you wrangling pirates, that fall out

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: In sharing that which you have pill'd from me!

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Which of you trembles not that looks on me?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: If not, that, I being queen, you bow like subjects,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Yet that, by you deposed, you quake like rebels?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: O gentle villain, do not turn away!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Foul wrinkled witch, what makest thou in my sight?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: But repetition of what thou hast marr'd;

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: That will I make before I let thee go.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Wert thou not banished on pain of death?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: I was; but I do find more pain in banishment

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Than death can yield me here by my abode.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: A husband and a son thou owest to me;

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And thou a kingdom; all of you allegiance:

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: The sorrow that I have, by right is yours,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And all the pleasures you usurp are mine.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: The curse my noble father laid on thee,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: When thou didst crown his warlike brows with paper

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And with thy scorns drew'st rivers from his eyes,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And then, to dry them, gavest the duke a clout

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Steep'd in the faultless blood of pretty Rutland--

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: His curses, then from bitterness of soul

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Denounced against thee, are all fall'n upon thee;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And God, not we, hath plagued thy bloody deed.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: So just is God, to right the innocent.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: O, 'twas the foulest deed to slay that babe,

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: And the most merciless that e'er was heard of!

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: Tyrants themselves wept when it was reported.

speaker: DORSET
text_entry: No man but prophesied revenge for it.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Northumberland, then present, wept to see it.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: What were you snarling all before I came,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Ready to catch each other by the throat,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And turn you all your hatred now on me?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Did York's dread curse prevail so much with heaven?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: That Henry's death, my lovely Edward's death,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Their kingdom's loss, my woful banishment,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Could all but answer for that peevish brat?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Can curses pierce the clouds and enter heaven?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Why, then, give way, dull clouds, to my quick curses!

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: If not by war, by surfeit die your king,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: As ours by murder, to make him a king!

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Edward thy son, which now is Prince of Wales,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: For Edward my son, which was Prince of Wales,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Die in his youth by like untimely violence!

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Thyself a queen, for me that was a queen,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Outlive thy glory, like my wretched self!

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Long mayst thou live to wail thy children's loss;

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And see another, as I see thee now,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Deck'd in thy rights, as thou art stall'd in mine!

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Long die thy happy days before thy death;

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And, after many lengthen'd hours of grief,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Die neither mother, wife, nor England's queen!

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Rivers and Dorset, you were standers by,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And so wast thou, Lord Hastings, when my son

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Was stabb'd with bloody daggers: God, I pray him,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: That none of you may live your natural age,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: But by some unlook'd accident cut off!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Have done thy charm, thou hateful wither'd hag!

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And leave out thee? stay, dog, for thou shalt hear me.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: If heaven have any grievous plague in store

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Exceeding those that I can wish upon thee,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: O, let them keep it till thy sins be ripe,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And then hurl down their indignation

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: On thee, the troubler of the poor world's peace!

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: The worm of conscience still begnaw thy soul!

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Thy friends suspect for traitors while thou livest,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And take deep traitors for thy dearest friends!

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: No sleep close up that deadly eye of thine,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Unless it be whilst some tormenting dream

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Affrights thee with a hell of ugly devils!

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Thou elvish-mark'd, abortive, rooting hog!

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Thou that wast seal'd in thy nativity

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: The slave of nature and the son of hell!

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Thou slander of thy mother's heavy womb!

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Thou loathed issue of thy father's loins!

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Thou rag of honour! thou detested--

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Margaret.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Richard!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Ha!

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: I call thee not.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I cry thee mercy then, for I had thought

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: That thou hadst call'd me all these bitter names.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Why, so I did; but look'd for no reply.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: O, let me make the period to my curse!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: 'Tis done by me, and ends in 'Margaret.'

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Thus have you breathed your curse against yourself.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Poor painted queen, vain flourish of my fortune!

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Why strew'st thou sugar on that bottled spider,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Whose deadly web ensnareth thee about?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Fool, fool! thou whet'st a knife to kill thyself.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: The time will come when thou shalt wish for me

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: To help thee curse that poisonous bunchback'd toad.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: False-boding woman, end thy frantic curse,

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Lest to thy harm thou move our patience.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Foul shame upon you! you have all moved mine.

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: Were you well served, you would be taught your duty.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: To serve me well, you all should do me duty,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Teach me to be your queen, and you my subjects:

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: O, serve me well, and teach yourselves that duty!

speaker: DORSET
text_entry: Dispute not with her; she is lunatic.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Peace, master marquess, you are malapert:

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Your fire-new stamp of honour is scarce current.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: O, that your young nobility could judge

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: What 'twere to lose it, and be miserable!

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: They that stand high have many blasts to shake them;

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And if they fall, they dash themselves to pieces.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Good counsel, marry: learn it, learn it, marquess.

speaker: DORSET
text_entry: It toucheth you, my lord, as much as me.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Yea, and much more: but I was born so high,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Our aery buildeth in the cedar's top,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And dallies with the wind and scorns the sun.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And turns the sun to shade; alas! alas!

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Witness my son, now in the shade of death;

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Whose bright out-shining beams thy cloudy wrath

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Hath in eternal darkness folded up.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Your aery buildeth in our aery's nest.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: O God, that seest it, do not suffer it!

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: As it was won with blood, lost be it so!

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Have done! for shame, if not for charity.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Urge neither charity nor shame to me:

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Uncharitably with me have you dealt,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And shamefully by you my hopes are butcher'd.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: My charity is outrage, life my shame

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And in that shame still live my sorrow's rage.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Have done, have done.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: O princely Buckingham I'll kiss thy hand,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: In sign of league and amity with thee:

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Now fair befal thee and thy noble house!

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Thy garments are not spotted with our blood,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Nor thou within the compass of my curse.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Nor no one here; for curses never pass

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: The lips of those that breathe them in the air.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: I'll not believe but they ascend the sky,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And there awake God's gentle-sleeping peace.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: O Buckingham, take heed of yonder dog!

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Look, when he fawns, he bites; and when he bites,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: His venom tooth will rankle to the death:

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Have not to do with him, beware of him;

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Sin, death, and hell have set their marks on him,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And all their ministers attend on him.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: What doth she say, my Lord of Buckingham?

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Nothing that I respect, my gracious lord.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: What, dost thou scorn me for my gentle counsel?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And soothe the devil that I warn thee from?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: O, but remember this another day,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: When he shall split thy very heart with sorrow,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And say poor Margaret was a prophetess!

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Live each of you the subjects to his hate,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And he to yours, and all of you to God's!

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Exit

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: My hair doth stand on end to hear her curses.

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: And so doth mine: I muse why she's at liberty.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I cannot blame her: by God's holy mother,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: She hath had too much wrong; and I repent

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: My part thereof that I have done to her.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: I never did her any, to my knowledge.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: But you have all the vantage of her wrong.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I was too hot to do somebody good,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: That is too cold in thinking of it now.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Marry, as for Clarence, he is well repaid,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: He is frank'd up to fatting for his pains

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: God pardon them that are the cause of it!

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: A virtuous and a Christian-like conclusion,

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: To pray for them that have done scathe to us.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: So do I ever:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Aside

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: being well-advised.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: For had I cursed now, I had cursed myself.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Enter CATESBY

speaker: CATESBY
text_entry: Madam, his majesty doth call for you,

speaker: CATESBY
text_entry: And for your grace; and you, my noble lords.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Catesby, we come. Lords, will you go with us?

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: Madam, we will attend your grace.

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: Exeunt all but GLOUCESTER

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I do the wrong, and first begin to brawl.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: The secret mischiefs that I set abroach

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I lay unto the grievous charge of others.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Clarence, whom I, indeed, have laid in darkness,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I do beweep to many simple gulls

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Namely, to Hastings, Derby, Buckingham;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And say it is the queen and her allies

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: That stir the king against the duke my brother.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Now, they believe it; and withal whet me

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To be revenged on Rivers, Vaughan, Grey:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: But then I sigh; and, with a piece of scripture,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Tell them that God bids us do good for evil:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And thus I clothe my naked villany

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: With old odd ends stolen out of holy writ;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And seem a saint, when most I play the devil.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Enter two Murderers

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: But, soft! here come my executioners.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: How now, my hardy, stout resolved mates!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Are you now going to dispatch this deed?

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: We are, my lord; and come to have the warrant

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: That we may be admitted where he is.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Well thought upon; I have it here about me.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Gives the warrant

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: When you have done, repair to Crosby Place.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: But, sirs, be sudden in the execution,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Withal obdurate, do not hear him plead;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: For Clarence is well-spoken, and perhaps

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: May move your hearts to pity if you mark him.

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: Tush!

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: Fear not, my lord, we will not stand to prate;

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: Talkers are no good doers: be assured

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: We come to use our hands and not our tongues.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Your eyes drop millstones, when fools' eyes drop tears:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I like you, lads; about your business straight;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Go, go, dispatch.

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: We will, my noble lord.

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: SCENE IV. London. The Tower.

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: Enter CLARENCE and BRAKENBURY

speaker: BRAKENBURY
text_entry: Why looks your grace so heavily today?

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: O, I have pass'd a miserable night,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: So full of ugly sights, of ghastly dreams,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: That, as I am a Christian faithful man,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: I would not spend another such a night,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Though 'twere to buy a world of happy days,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: So full of dismal terror was the time!

speaker: BRAKENBURY
text_entry: What was your dream? I long to hear you tell it.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Methoughts that I had broken from the Tower,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: And was embark'd to cross to Burgundy;

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: And, in my company, my brother Gloucester;

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Who from my cabin tempted me to walk

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Upon the hatches: thence we looked toward England,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: And cited up a thousand fearful times,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: During the wars of York and Lancaster

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: That had befall'n us. As we paced along

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Upon the giddy footing of the hatches,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Methought that Gloucester stumbled; and, in falling,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Struck me, that thought to stay him, overboard,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Into the tumbling billows of the main.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Lord, Lord! methought, what pain it was to drown!

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: What dreadful noise of waters in mine ears!

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: What ugly sights of death within mine eyes!

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Methought I saw a thousand fearful wrecks;

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Ten thousand men that fishes gnaw'd upon;

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Wedges of gold, great anchors, heaps of pearl,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Inestimable stones, unvalued jewels,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: All scatter'd in the bottom of the sea:

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Some lay in dead men's skulls; and, in those holes

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Where eyes did once inhabit, there were crept,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: As 'twere in scorn of eyes, reflecting gems,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Which woo'd the slimy bottom of the deep,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: And mock'd the dead bones that lay scatter'd by.

speaker: BRAKENBURY
text_entry: Had you such leisure in the time of death

speaker: BRAKENBURY
text_entry: To gaze upon the secrets of the deep?

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Methought I had; and often did I strive

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: To yield the ghost: but still the envious flood

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Kept in my soul, and would not let it forth

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: To seek the empty, vast and wandering air;

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: But smother'd it within my panting bulk,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Which almost burst to belch it in the sea.

speaker: BRAKENBURY
text_entry: Awaked you not with this sore agony?

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: O, no, my dream was lengthen'd after life;

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: O, then began the tempest to my soul,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Who pass'd, methought, the melancholy flood,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: With that grim ferryman which poets write of,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Unto the kingdom of perpetual night.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: The first that there did greet my stranger soul,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Was my great father-in-law, renowned Warwick;

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Who cried aloud, 'What scourge for perjury

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Can this dark monarchy afford false Clarence?'

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: And so he vanish'd: then came wandering by

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: A shadow like an angel, with bright hair

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Dabbled in blood; and he squeak'd out aloud,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: 'Clarence is come; false, fleeting, perjured Clarence,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: That stabb'd me in the field by Tewksbury;

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Seize on him, Furies, take him to your torments!'

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: With that, methoughts, a legion of foul fiends

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Environ'd me about, and howled in mine ears

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Such hideous cries, that with the very noise

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: I trembling waked, and for a season after

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Could not believe but that I was in hell,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Such terrible impression made the dream.

speaker: BRAKENBURY
text_entry: No marvel, my lord, though it affrighted you;

speaker: BRAKENBURY
text_entry: I promise, I am afraid to hear you tell it.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: O Brakenbury, I have done those things,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Which now bear evidence against my soul,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: For Edward's sake; and see how he requites me!

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: O God! if my deep prayers cannot appease thee,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: But thou wilt be avenged on my misdeeds,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Yet execute thy wrath in me alone,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: O, spare my guiltless wife and my poor children!

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: I pray thee, gentle keeper, stay by me;

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: My soul is heavy, and I fain would sleep.

speaker: BRAKENBURY
text_entry: I will, my lord: God give your grace good rest!

speaker: BRAKENBURY
text_entry: CLARENCE sleeps

speaker: BRAKENBURY
text_entry: Sorrow breaks seasons and reposing hours,

speaker: BRAKENBURY
text_entry: Makes the night morning, and the noon-tide night.

speaker: BRAKENBURY
text_entry: Princes have but their tides for their glories,

speaker: BRAKENBURY
text_entry: An outward honour for an inward toil;

speaker: BRAKENBURY
text_entry: And, for unfelt imagination,

speaker: BRAKENBURY
text_entry: They often feel a world of restless cares:

speaker: BRAKENBURY
text_entry: So that, betwixt their tides and low names,

speaker: BRAKENBURY
text_entry: There's nothing differs but the outward fame.

speaker: BRAKENBURY
text_entry: Enter the two Murderers

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: Ho! who's here?

speaker: BRAKENBURY
text_entry: In God's name what are you, and how came you hither?

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: I would speak with Clarence, and I came hither on my legs.

speaker: BRAKENBURY
text_entry: Yea, are you so brief?

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: O sir, it is better to be brief than tedious. Show

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: him our commission; talk no more.

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: BRAKENBURY reads it

speaker: BRAKENBURY
text_entry: I am, in this, commanded to deliver

speaker: BRAKENBURY
text_entry: The noble Duke of Clarence to your hands:

speaker: BRAKENBURY
text_entry: I will not reason what is meant hereby,

speaker: BRAKENBURY
text_entry: Because I will be guiltless of the meaning.

speaker: BRAKENBURY
text_entry: Here are the keys, there sits the duke asleep:

speaker: BRAKENBURY
text_entry: I'll to the king; and signify to him

speaker: BRAKENBURY
text_entry: That thus I have resign'd my charge to you.

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: Do so, it is a point of wisdom: fare you well.

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: Exit BRAKENBURY

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: What, shall we stab him as he sleeps?

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: No; then he will say 'twas done cowardly, when he wakes.

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: When he wakes! why, fool, he shall never wake till

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: the judgment-day.

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: Why, then he will say we stabbed him sleeping.

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: The urging of that word 'judgment' hath bred a kind

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: of remorse in me.

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: What, art thou afraid?

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: Not to kill him, having a warrant for it; but to be

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: damned for killing him, from which no warrant can defend us.

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: I thought thou hadst been resolute.

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: So I am, to let him live.

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: Back to the Duke of Gloucester, tell him so.

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: I pray thee, stay a while: I hope my holy humour

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: will change; 'twas wont to hold me but while one

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: would tell twenty.

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: How dost thou feel thyself now?

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: 'Faith, some certain dregs of conscience are yet

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: within me.

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: Remember our reward, when the deed is done.

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: 'Zounds, he dies: I had forgot the reward.

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: Where is thy conscience now?

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: In the Duke of Gloucester's purse.

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: So when he opens his purse to give us our reward,

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: thy conscience flies out.

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: Let it go; there's few or none will entertain it.

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: How if it come to thee again?

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: I'll not meddle with it: it is a dangerous thing: it

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: makes a man a coward: a man cannot steal, but it

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: accuseth him; he cannot swear, but it cheques him;

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: he cannot lie with his neighbour's wife, but it

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: detects him: 'tis a blushing shamefast spirit that

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: mutinies in a man's bosom; it fills one full of

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: obstacles: it made me once restore a purse of gold

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: that I found; it beggars any man that keeps it: it

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: is turned out of all towns and cities for a

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: dangerous thing; and every man that means to live

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: well endeavours to trust to himself and to live

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: without it.

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: 'Zounds, it is even now at my elbow, persuading me

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: not to kill the duke.

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: Take the devil in thy mind, and relieve him not: he

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: would insinuate with thee but to make thee sigh.

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: Tut, I am strong-framed, he cannot prevail with me,

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: I warrant thee.

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: Spoke like a tail fellow that respects his

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: reputation. Come, shall we to this gear?

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: Take him over the costard with the hilts of thy

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: sword, and then we will chop him in the malmsey-butt

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: in the next room.

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: O excellent devise! make a sop of him.

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: Hark! he stirs: shall I strike?

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: No, first let's reason with him.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Where art thou, keeper? give me a cup of wine.

speaker: Second murderer
text_entry: You shall have wine enough, my lord, anon.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: In God's name, what art thou?

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: A man, as you are.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: But not, as I am, royal.

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: Nor you, as we are, loyal.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Thy voice is thunder, but thy looks are humble.

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: My voice is now the king's, my looks mine own.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: How darkly and how deadly dost thou speak!

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Your eyes do menace me: why look you pale?

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Who sent you hither? Wherefore do you come?

speaker: Both
text_entry: To, to, to--

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: To murder me?

speaker: Both
text_entry: Ay, ay.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: You scarcely have the hearts to tell me so,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: And therefore cannot have the hearts to do it.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Wherein, my friends, have I offended you?

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: Offended us you have not, but the king.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: I shall be reconciled to him again.

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: Never, my lord; therefore prepare to die.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Are you call'd forth from out a world of men

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: To slay the innocent? What is my offence?

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Where are the evidence that do accuse me?

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: What lawful quest have given their verdict up

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Unto the frowning judge? or who pronounced

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: The bitter sentence of poor Clarence' death?

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Before I be convict by course of law,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: To threaten me with death is most unlawful.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: I charge you, as you hope to have redemption

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: By Christ's dear blood shed for our grievous sins,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: That you depart and lay no hands on me

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: The deed you undertake is damnable.

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: What we will do, we do upon command.

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: And he that hath commanded is the king.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Erroneous vassal! the great King of kings

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Hath in the tables of his law commanded

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: That thou shalt do no murder: and wilt thou, then,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Spurn at his edict and fulfil a man's?

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Take heed; for he holds vengeance in his hands,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: To hurl upon their heads that break his law.

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: And that same vengeance doth he hurl on thee,

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: For false forswearing and for murder too:

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: Thou didst receive the holy sacrament,

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: To fight in quarrel of the house of Lancaster.

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: And, like a traitor to the name of God,

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: Didst break that vow; and with thy treacherous blade

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: Unrip'dst the bowels of thy sovereign's son.

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: Whom thou wert sworn to cherish and defend.

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: How canst thou urge God's dreadful law to us,

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: When thou hast broke it in so dear degree?

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Alas! for whose sake did I that ill deed?

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: For Edward, for my brother, for his sake: Why, sirs,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: He sends ye not to murder me for this

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: For in this sin he is as deep as I.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: If God will be revenged for this deed.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: O, know you yet, he doth it publicly,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Take not the quarrel from his powerful arm;

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: He needs no indirect nor lawless course

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: To cut off those that have offended him.

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: Who made thee, then, a bloody minister,

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: When gallant-springing brave Plantagenet,

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: That princely novice, was struck dead by thee?

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: My brother's love, the devil, and my rage.

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: Thy brother's love, our duty, and thy fault,

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: Provoke us hither now to slaughter thee.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Oh, if you love my brother, hate not me;

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: I am his brother, and I love him well.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: If you be hired for meed, go back again,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: And I will send you to my brother Gloucester,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Who shall reward you better for my life

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Than Edward will for tidings of my death.

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: You are deceived, your brother Gloucester hates you.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: O, no, he loves me, and he holds me dear:

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Go you to him from me.

speaker: Both
text_entry: Ay, so we will.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Tell him, when that our princely father York

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Bless'd his three sons with his victorious arm,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: And charged us from his soul to love each other,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: He little thought of this divided friendship:

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Bid Gloucester think of this, and he will weep.

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: Ay, millstones; as be lesson'd us to weep.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: O, do not slander him, for he is kind.

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: Right,

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: As snow in harvest. Thou deceivest thyself:

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: 'Tis he that sent us hither now to slaughter thee.

speaker: CLARENCE
