text_entry: It cannot be; for when I parted with him,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: He hugg'd me in his arms, and swore, with sobs,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: That he would labour my delivery.

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: Why, so he doth, now he delivers thee

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: From this world's thraldom to the joys of heaven.

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: Make peace with God, for you must die, my lord.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Hast thou that holy feeling in thy soul,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: To counsel me to make my peace with God,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: And art thou yet to thy own soul so blind,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: That thou wilt war with God by murdering me?

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Ah, sirs, consider, he that set you on

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: To do this deed will hate you for the deed.

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: What shall we do?

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Relent, and save your souls.

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: Relent! 'tis cowardly and womanish.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Not to relent is beastly, savage, devilish.

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Which of you, if you were a prince's son,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Being pent from liberty, as I am now,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: if two such murderers as yourselves came to you,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Would not entreat for life?

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: My friend, I spy some pity in thy looks:

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: O, if thine eye be not a flatterer,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: Come thou on my side, and entreat for me,

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: As you would beg, were you in my distress

speaker: CLARENCE
text_entry: A begging prince what beggar pities not?

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: Look behind you, my lord.

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: Take that, and that: if all this will not do,

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: Stabs him

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: I'll drown you in the malmsey-butt within.

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: Exit, with the body

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: A bloody deed, and desperately dispatch'd!

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: How fain, like Pilate, would I wash my hands

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: Of this most grievous guilty murder done!

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: Re-enter First Murderer

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: How now! what mean'st thou, that thou help'st me not?

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: By heavens, the duke shall know how slack thou art!

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: I would he knew that I had saved his brother!

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: Take thou the fee, and tell him what I say;

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: For I repent me that the duke is slain.

speaker: Second Murderer
text_entry: Exit

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: So do not I: go, coward as thou art.

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: Now must I hide his body in some hole,

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: Until the duke take order for his burial:

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: And when I have my meed, I must away;

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: For this will out, and here I must not stay.

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: ACT II

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: SCENE I. London. The palace.

speaker: First Murderer
text_entry: Flourish. Enter KING EDWARD IV sick, QUEEN  ELIZABETH, DORSET, RIVERS, HASTINGS, BUCKINGHAM, GREY, and others

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Why, so: now have I done a good day's work:

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: You peers, continue this united league:

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: I every day expect an embassage

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: From my Redeemer to redeem me hence;

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: And now in peace my soul shall part to heaven,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Since I have set my friends at peace on earth.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Rivers and Hastings, take each other's hand;

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Dissemble not your hatred, swear your love.

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: By heaven, my heart is purged from grudging hate:

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: And with my hand I seal my true heart's love.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: So thrive I, as I truly swear the like!

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Take heed you dally not before your king;

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Lest he that is the supreme King of kings

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Confound your hidden falsehood, and award

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Either of you to be the other's end.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: So prosper I, as I swear perfect love!

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: And I, as I love Hastings with my heart!

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Madam, yourself are not exempt in this,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Nor your son Dorset, Buckingham, nor you;

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: You have been factious one against the other,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Wife, love Lord Hastings, let him kiss your hand;

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: And what you do, do it unfeignedly.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Here, Hastings; I will never more remember

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Our former hatred, so thrive I and mine!

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Dorset, embrace him; Hastings, love lord marquess.

speaker: DORSET
text_entry: This interchange of love, I here protest,

speaker: DORSET
text_entry: Upon my part shall be unviolable.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: And so swear I, my lord

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: They embrace

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Now, princely Buckingham, seal thou this league

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: With thy embracements to my wife's allies,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: And make me happy in your unity.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Whenever Buckingham doth turn his hate

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: On you or yours,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: To the Queen

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: but with all duteous love

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Doth cherish you and yours, God punish me

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: With hate in those where I expect most love!

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: When I have most need to employ a friend,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: And most assured that he is a friend

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Deep, hollow, treacherous, and full of guile,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Be he unto me! this do I beg of God,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: When I am cold in zeal to yours.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: A pleasing cordial, princely Buckingham,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: is this thy vow unto my sickly heart.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: There wanteth now our brother Gloucester here,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: To make the perfect period of this peace.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: And, in good time, here comes the noble duke.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Enter GLOUCESTER

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Good morrow to my sovereign king and queen:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And, princely peers, a happy time of day!

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Happy, indeed, as we have spent the day.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Brother, we done deeds of charity;

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Made peace enmity, fair love of hate,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Between these swelling wrong-incensed peers.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: A blessed labour, my most sovereign liege:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Amongst this princely heap, if any here,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: By false intelligence, or wrong surmise,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Hold me a foe;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: If I unwittingly, or in my rage,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Have aught committed that is hardly borne

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: By any in this presence, I desire

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To reconcile me to his friendly peace:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: 'Tis death to me to be at enmity;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I hate it, and desire all good men's love.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: First, madam, I entreat true peace of you,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Which I will purchase with my duteous service;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Of you, my noble cousin Buckingham,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: If ever any grudge were lodged between us;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Of you, Lord Rivers, and, Lord Grey, of you;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: That without desert have frown'd on me;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Dukes, earls, lords, gentlemen; indeed, of all.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I do not know that Englishman alive

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: With whom my soul is any jot at odds

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: More than the infant that is born to-night

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I thank my God for my humility.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: A holy day shall this be kept hereafter:

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: I would to God all strifes were well compounded.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: My sovereign liege, I do beseech your majesty

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: To take our brother Clarence to your grace.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Why, madam, have I offer'd love for this

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To be so bouted in this royal presence?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Who knows not that the noble duke is dead?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: They all start

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: You do him injury to scorn his corse.

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: Who knows not he is dead! who knows he is?

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: All seeing heaven, what a world is this!

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Look I so pale, Lord Dorset, as the rest?

speaker: DORSET
text_entry: Ay, my good lord; and no one in this presence

speaker: DORSET
text_entry: But his red colour hath forsook his cheeks.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Is Clarence dead? the order was reversed.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: But he, poor soul, by your first order died,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And that a winged Mercury did bear:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Some tardy cripple bore the countermand,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: That came too lag to see him buried.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: God grant that some, less noble and less loyal,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Nearer in bloody thoughts, but not in blood,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Deserve not worse than wretched Clarence did,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And yet go current from suspicion!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Enter DERBY

speaker: DORSET
text_entry: A boon, my sovereign, for my service done!

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: I pray thee, peace: my soul is full of sorrow.

speaker: DORSET
text_entry: I will not rise, unless your highness grant.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Then speak at once what is it thou demand'st.

speaker: DORSET
text_entry: The forfeit, sovereign, of my servant's life;

speaker: DORSET
text_entry: Who slew to-day a righteous gentleman

speaker: DORSET
text_entry: Lately attendant on the Duke of Norfolk.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Have a tongue to doom my brother's death,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: And shall the same give pardon to a slave?

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: My brother slew no man; his fault was thought,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: And yet his punishment was cruel death.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Who sued to me for him? who, in my rage,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Kneel'd at my feet, and bade me be advised

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Who spake of brotherhood? who spake of love?

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Who told me how the poor soul did forsake

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: The mighty Warwick, and did fight for me?

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Who told me, in the field by Tewksbury

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: When Oxford had me down, he rescued me,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: And said, 'Dear brother, live, and be a king'?

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Who told me, when we both lay in the field

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Frozen almost to death, how he did lap me

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Even in his own garments, and gave himself,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: All thin and naked, to the numb cold night?

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: All this from my remembrance brutish wrath

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Sinfully pluck'd, and not a man of you

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Had so much grace to put it in my mind.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: But when your carters or your waiting-vassals

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Have done a drunken slaughter, and defaced

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: The precious image of our dear Redeemer,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: You straight are on your knees for pardon, pardon;

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: And I unjustly too, must grant it you

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: But for my brother not a man would speak,

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Nor I, ungracious, speak unto myself

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: For him, poor soul. The proudest of you all

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Have been beholding to him in his life;

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Yet none of you would once plead for his life.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: O God, I fear thy justice will take hold

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: On me, and you, and mine, and yours for this!

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Come, Hastings, help me to my closet.

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Oh, poor Clarence!

speaker: KING EDWARD IV
text_entry: Exeunt some with KING EDWARD IV and QUEEN MARGARET

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: This is the fruit of rashness! Mark'd you not

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: How that the guilty kindred of the queen

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Look'd pale when they did hear of Clarence' death?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: O, they did urge it still unto the king!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: God will revenge it. But come, let us in,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To comfort Edward with our company.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: We wait upon your grace.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: SCENE II. The palace.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Enter the DUCHESS OF YORK, with the two children of CLARENCE

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Tell me, good grandam, is our father dead?

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: No, boy.

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Why do you wring your hands, and beat your breast,

speaker: Boy
text_entry: And cry 'O Clarence, my unhappy son!'

speaker: Girl
text_entry: Why do you look on us, and shake your head,

speaker: Girl
text_entry: And call us wretches, orphans, castaways

speaker: Girl
text_entry: If that our noble father be alive?

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: My pretty cousins, you mistake me much;

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: I do lament the sickness of the king.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: As loath to lose him, not your father's death;

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: It were lost sorrow to wail one that's lost.

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Then, grandam, you conclude that he is dead.

speaker: Boy
text_entry: The king my uncle is to blame for this:

speaker: Boy
text_entry: God will revenge it; whom I will importune

speaker: Boy
text_entry: With daily prayers all to that effect.

speaker: Girl
text_entry: And so will I.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Peace, children, peace! the king doth love you well:

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Incapable and shallow innocents,

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: You cannot guess who caused your father's death.

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Grandam, we can; for my good uncle Gloucester

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Told me, the king, provoked by the queen,

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Devised impeachments to imprison him :

speaker: Boy
text_entry: And when my uncle told me so, he wept,

speaker: Boy
text_entry: And hugg'd me in his arm, and kindly kiss'd my cheek;

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Bade me rely on him as on my father,

speaker: Boy
text_entry: And he would love me dearly as his child.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Oh, that deceit should steal such gentle shapes,

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: And with a virtuous vizard hide foul guile!

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: He is my son; yea, and therein my shame;

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Yet from my dugs he drew not this deceit.

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Think you my uncle did dissemble, grandam?

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Ay, boy.

speaker: Boy
text_entry: I cannot think it. Hark! what noise is this?

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Enter QUEEN ELIZABETH, with her hair about her ears; RIVERS, and DORSET after her

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Oh, who shall hinder me to wail and weep,

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: To chide my fortune, and torment myself?

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: I'll join with black despair against my soul,

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: And to myself become an enemy.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: What means this scene of rude impatience?

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: To make an act of tragic violence:

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Edward, my lord, your son, our king, is dead.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Why grow the branches now the root is wither'd?

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Why wither not the leaves the sap being gone?

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: If you will live, lament; if die, be brief,

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: That our swift-winged souls may catch the king's;

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Or, like obedient subjects, follow him

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: To his new kingdom of perpetual rest.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Ah, so much interest have I in thy sorrow

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: As I had title in thy noble husband!

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: I have bewept a worthy husband's death,

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: And lived by looking on his images:

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: But now two mirrors of his princely semblance

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Are crack'd in pieces by malignant death,

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: And I for comfort have but one false glass,

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Which grieves me when I see my shame in him.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Thou art a widow; yet thou art a mother,

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: And hast the comfort of thy children left thee:

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: But death hath snatch'd my husband from mine arms,

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: And pluck'd two crutches from my feeble limbs,

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Edward and Clarence. O, what cause have I,

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Thine being but a moiety of my grief,

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: To overgo thy plaints and drown thy cries!

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Good aunt, you wept not for our father's death;

speaker: Boy
text_entry: How can we aid you with our kindred tears?

speaker: Girl
text_entry: Our fatherless distress was left unmoan'd;

speaker: Girl
text_entry: Your widow-dolour likewise be unwept!

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Give me no help in lamentation;

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: I am not barren to bring forth complaints

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: All springs reduce their currents to mine eyes,

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: That I, being govern'd by the watery moon,

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: May send forth plenteous tears to drown the world!

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Oh for my husband, for my dear lord Edward!

speaker: Children
text_entry: Oh for our father, for our dear lord Clarence!

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Alas for both, both mine, Edward and Clarence!

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: What stay had I but Edward? and he's gone.

speaker: Children
text_entry: What stay had we but Clarence? and he's gone.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: What stays had I but they? and they are gone.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Was never widow had so dear a loss!

speaker: Children
text_entry: Were never orphans had so dear a loss!

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Was never mother had so dear a loss!

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Alas, I am the mother of these moans!

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Their woes are parcell'd, mine are general.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: She for an Edward weeps, and so do I;

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: I for a Clarence weep, so doth not she:

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: These babes for Clarence weep and so do I;

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: I for an Edward weep, so do not they:

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Alas, you three, on me, threefold distress'd,

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Pour all your tears! I am your sorrow's nurse,

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: And I will pamper it with lamentations.

speaker: DORSET
text_entry: Comfort, dear mother: God is much displeased

speaker: DORSET
text_entry: That you take with unthankfulness, his doing:

speaker: DORSET
text_entry: In common worldly things, 'tis call'd ungrateful,

speaker: DORSET
text_entry: With dull unwilligness to repay a debt

speaker: DORSET
text_entry: Which with a bounteous hand was kindly lent;

speaker: DORSET
text_entry: Much more to be thus opposite with heaven,

speaker: DORSET
text_entry: For it requires the royal debt it lent you.

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: Madam, bethink you, like a careful mother,

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: Of the young prince your son: send straight for him

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: Let him be crown'd; in him your comfort lives:

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: Drown desperate sorrow in dead Edward's grave,

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: And plant your joys in living Edward's throne.

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: Enter GLOUCESTER, BUCKINGHAM, DERBY, HASTINGS, and RATCLIFF

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Madam, have comfort: all of us have cause

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To wail the dimming of our shining star;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: But none can cure their harms by wailing them.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Madam, my mother, I do cry you mercy;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I did not see your grace: humbly on my knee

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I crave your blessing.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: God bless thee; and put meekness in thy mind,

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Love, charity, obedience, and true duty!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: [Aside]  Amen; and make me die a good old man!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: That is the butt-end of a mother's blessing:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I marvel why her grace did leave it out.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: You cloudy princes and heart-sorrowing peers,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: That bear this mutual heavy load of moan,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Now cheer each other in each other's love

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Though we have spent our harvest of this king,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: We are to reap the harvest of his son.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: The broken rancour of your high-swoln hearts,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: But lately splinter'd, knit, and join'd together,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Must gently be preserved, cherish'd, and kept:

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Me seemeth good, that, with some little train,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Forthwith from Ludlow the young prince be fetch'd

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Hither to London, to be crown'd our king.

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: Why with some little train, my Lord of Buckingham?

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Marry, my lord, lest, by a multitude,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: The new-heal'd wound of malice should break out,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Which would be so much the more dangerous

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: By how much the estate is green and yet ungovern'd:

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Where every horse bears his commanding rein,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: And may direct his course as please himself,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: As well the fear of harm, as harm apparent,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: In my opinion, ought to be prevented.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I hope the king made peace with all of us

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And the compact is firm and true in me.

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: And so in me; and so, I think, in all:

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: Yet, since it is but green, it should be put

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: To no apparent likelihood of breach,

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: Which haply by much company might be urged:

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: Therefore I say with noble Buckingham,

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: That it is meet so few should fetch the prince.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: And so say I.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Then be it so; and go we to determine

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Who they shall be that straight shall post to Ludlow.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Madam, and you, my mother, will you go

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To give your censures in this weighty business?

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: With all our harts.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Exeunt all but BUCKINGHAM and GLOUCESTER

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: My lord, whoever journeys to the Prince,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: For God's sake, let not us two be behind;

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: For, by the way, I'll sort occasion,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: As index to the story we late talk'd of,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: To part the queen's proud kindred from the king.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: My other self, my counsel's consistory,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: My oracle, my prophet! My dear cousin,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I, like a child, will go by thy direction.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Towards Ludlow then, for we'll not stay behind.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: SCENE III. London. A street.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Enter two Citizens meeting

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: Neighbour, well met: whither away so fast?

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: I promise you, I scarcely know myself:

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: Hear you the news abroad?

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: Ay, that the king is dead.

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: Bad news, by'r lady; seldom comes the better:

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: I fear, I fear 'twill prove a troublous world.

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: Enter another Citizen

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: Neighbours, God speed!

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: Give you good morrow, sir.

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: Doth this news hold of good King Edward's death?

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: Ay, sir, it is too true; God help the while!

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: Then, masters, look to see a troublous world.

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: No, no; by God's good grace his son shall reign.

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: Woe to the land that's govern'd by a child!

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: In him there is a hope of government,

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: That in his nonage council under him,

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: And in his full and ripen'd years himself,

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: No doubt, shall then and till then govern well.

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: So stood the state when Henry the Sixth

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: Was crown'd in Paris but at nine months old.

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: Stood the state so? No, no, good friends, God wot;

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: For then this land was famously enrich'd

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: With politic grave counsel; then the king

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: Had virtuous uncles to protect his grace.

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: Why, so hath this, both by the father and mother.

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: Better it were they all came by the father,

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: Or by the father there were none at all;

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: For emulation now, who shall be nearest,

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: Will touch us all too near, if God prevent not.

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: O, full of danger is the Duke of Gloucester!

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: And the queen's sons and brothers haught and proud:

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: And were they to be ruled, and not to rule,

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: This sickly land might solace as before.

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: Come, come, we fear the worst; all shall be well.

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: When clouds appear, wise men put on their cloaks;

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: When great leaves fall, the winter is at hand;

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: When the sun sets, who doth not look for night?

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: Untimely storms make men expect a dearth.

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: All may be well; but, if God sort it so,

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: 'Tis more than we deserve, or I expect.

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: Truly, the souls of men are full of dread:

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: Ye cannot reason almost with a man

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: That looks not heavily and full of fear.

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: Before the times of change, still is it so:

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: By a divine instinct men's minds mistrust

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: Ensuing dangers; as by proof, we see

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: The waters swell before a boisterous storm.

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: But leave it all to God. whither away?

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: Marry, we were sent for to the justices.

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: And so was I: I'll bear you company.

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: SCENE IV. London. The palace.

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: Enter the ARCHBISHOP OF YORK, young YORK, QUEEN ELIZABETH, and the DUCHESS OF YORK

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
text_entry: Last night, I hear, they lay at Northampton;

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
text_entry: At Stony-Stratford will they be to-night:

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
text_entry: To-morrow, or next day, they will be here.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: I long with all my heart to see the prince:

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: I hope he is much grown since last I saw him.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: But I hear, no; they say my son of York

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Hath almost overta'en him in his growth.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Ay, mother; but I would not have it so.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Why, my young cousin, it is good to grow.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Grandam, one night, as we did sit at supper,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: My uncle Rivers talk'd how I did grow

speaker: YORK
text_entry: More than my brother: 'Ay,' quoth my uncle

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Gloucester,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: 'Small herbs have grace, great weeds do grow apace:'

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And since, methinks, I would not grow so fast,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Because sweet flowers are slow and weeds make haste.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Good faith, good faith, the saying did not hold

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: In him that did object the same to thee;

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: He was the wretched'st thing when he was young,

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: So long a-growing and so leisurely,

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: That, if this rule were true, he should be gracious.

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
text_entry: Why, madam, so, no doubt, he is.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: I hope he is; but yet let mothers doubt.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Now, by my troth, if I had been remember'd,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: I could have given my uncle's grace a flout,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: To touch his growth nearer than he touch'd mine.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: How, my pretty York? I pray thee, let me hear it.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Marry, they say my uncle grew so fast

speaker: YORK
text_entry: That he could gnaw a crust at two hours old

speaker: YORK
text_entry: 'Twas full two years ere I could get a tooth.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Grandam, this would have been a biting jest.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: I pray thee, pretty York, who told thee this?

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Grandam, his nurse.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: His nurse! why, she was dead ere thou wert born.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: If 'twere not she, I cannot tell who told me.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: A parlous boy: go to, you are too shrewd.

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
text_entry: Good madam, be not angry with the child.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Pitchers have ears.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Enter a Messenger

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
text_entry: Here comes a messenger. What news?

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Such news, my lord, as grieves me to unfold.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: How fares the prince?

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Well, madam, and in health.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: What is thy news then?

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Lord Rivers and Lord Grey are sent to Pomfret,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: With them Sir Thomas Vaughan, prisoners.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Who hath committed them?

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: The mighty dukes

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Gloucester and Buckingham.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: For what offence?

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: The sum of all I can, I have disclosed;

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Why or for what these nobles were committed

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Is all unknown to me, my gracious lady.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Ay me, I see the downfall of our house!

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: The tiger now hath seized the gentle hind;

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Insulting tyranny begins to jet

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Upon the innocent and aweless throne:

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Welcome, destruction, death, and massacre!

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: I see, as in a map, the end of all.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Accursed and unquiet wrangling days,

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: How many of you have mine eyes beheld!

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: My husband lost his life to get the crown;

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: And often up and down my sons were toss'd,

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: For me to joy and weep their gain and loss:

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: And being seated, and domestic broils

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Clean over-blown, themselves, the conquerors.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Make war upon themselves; blood against blood,

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Self against self: O, preposterous

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: And frantic outrage, end thy damned spleen;

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Or let me die, to look on death no more!

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Come, come, my boy; we will to sanctuary.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Madam, farewell.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: I'll go along with you.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: You have no cause.

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
text_entry: My gracious lady, go;

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
text_entry: And thither bear your treasure and your goods.

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
text_entry: For my part, I'll resign unto your grace

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
text_entry: The seal I keep: and so betide to me

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
text_entry: As well I tender you and all of yours!

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
text_entry: Come, I'll conduct you to the sanctuary.

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
text_entry: ACT III

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
text_entry: SCENE I. London. A street.

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
text_entry: The trumpets sound. Enter the young PRINCE EDWARD, GLOUCESTER, BUCKINGHAM, CARDINAL, CATESBY, and others

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Welcome, sweet prince, to London, to your chamber.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Welcome, dear cousin, my thoughts' sovereign

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: The weary way hath made you melancholy.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: No, uncle; but our crosses on the way

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Have made it tedious, wearisome, and heavy

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: I want more uncles here to welcome me.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Sweet prince, the untainted virtue of your years

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Hath not yet dived into the world's deceit

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Nor more can you distinguish of a man

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Than of his outward show; which, God he knows,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Seldom or never jumpeth with the heart.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Those uncles which you want were dangerous;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Your grace attended to their sugar'd words,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: But look'd not on the poison of their hearts :

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: God keep you from them, and from such false friends!

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: God keep me from false friends! but they were none.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: My lord, the mayor of London comes to greet you.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Enter the Lord Mayor and his train

speaker: Lord Mayor
text_entry: God bless your grace with health and happy days!

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: I thank you, good my lord; and thank you all.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: I thought my mother, and my brother York,

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Would long ere this have met us on the way

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Fie, what a slug is Hastings, that he comes not

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: To tell us whether they will come or no!

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Enter HASTINGS

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: And, in good time, here comes the sweating lord.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Welcome, my lord: what, will our mother come?

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: On what occasion, God he knows, not I,

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: The queen your mother, and your brother York,

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Have taken sanctuary: the tender prince

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Would fain have come with me to meet your grace,

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: But by his mother was perforce withheld.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Fie, what an indirect and peevish course

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Is this of hers! Lord cardinal, will your grace

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Persuade the queen to send the Duke of York

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Unto his princely brother presently?

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: If she deny, Lord Hastings, go with him,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: And from her jealous arms pluck him perforce.

speaker: CARDINAL
text_entry: My Lord of Buckingham, if my weak oratory

speaker: CARDINAL
text_entry: Can from his mother win the Duke of York,

speaker: CARDINAL
text_entry: Anon expect him here; but if she be obdurate

speaker: CARDINAL
text_entry: To mild entreaties, God in heaven forbid

speaker: CARDINAL
text_entry: We should infringe the holy privilege

speaker: CARDINAL
text_entry: Of blessed sanctuary! not for all this land

speaker: CARDINAL
text_entry: Would I be guilty of so deep a sin.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: You are too senseless--obstinate, my lord,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Too ceremonious and traditional

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Weigh it but with the grossness of this age,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: You break not sanctuary in seizing him.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: The benefit thereof is always granted

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: To those whose dealings have deserved the place,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: And those who have the wit to claim the place:

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: This prince hath neither claim'd it nor deserved it;

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: And therefore, in mine opinion, cannot have it:

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Then, taking him from thence that is not there,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: You break no privilege nor charter there.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Oft have I heard of sanctuary men;

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: But sanctuary children ne'er till now.

speaker: CARDINAL
text_entry: My lord, you shall o'er-rule my mind for once.

speaker: CARDINAL
text_entry: Come on, Lord Hastings, will you go with me?

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: I go, my lord.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Good lords, make all the speedy haste you may.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Exeunt CARDINAL and HASTINGS

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Say, uncle Gloucester, if our brother come,

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Where shall we sojourn till our coronation?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Where it seems best unto your royal self.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: If I may counsel you, some day or two

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Your highness shall repose you at the Tower:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Then where you please, and shall be thought most fit

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: For your best health and recreation.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: I do not like the Tower, of any place.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Did Julius Caesar build that place, my lord?

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: He did, my gracious lord, begin that place;

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Which, since, succeeding ages have re-edified.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Is it upon record, or else reported

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Successively from age to age, he built it?

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Upon record, my gracious lord.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: But say, my lord, it were not register'd,

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Methinks the truth should live from age to age,

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: As 'twere retail'd to all posterity,

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Even to the general all-ending day.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: [Aside]  So wise so young, they say, do never

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: live long.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: What say you, uncle?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I say, without characters, fame lives long.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Aside

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Thus, like the formal vice, Iniquity,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I moralize two meanings in one word.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: That Julius Caesar was a famous man;

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: With what his valour did enrich his wit,

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: His wit set down to make his valour live

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Death makes no conquest of this conqueror;

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: For now he lives in fame, though not in life.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: I'll tell you what, my cousin Buckingham,--

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: What, my gracious lord?

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: An if I live until I be a man,

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: I'll win our ancient right in France again,

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Or die a soldier, as I lived a king.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: [Aside]  Short summers lightly have a forward spring.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Enter young YORK, HASTINGS, and the CARDINAL

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Now, in good time, here comes the Duke of York.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Richard of York! how fares our loving brother?

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Well, my dread lord; so must I call you now.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Ay, brother, to our grief, as it is yours:

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Too late he died that might have kept that title,

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Which by his death hath lost much majesty.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: How fares our cousin, noble Lord of York?

speaker: YORK
text_entry: I thank you, gentle uncle. O, my lord,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: You said that idle weeds are fast in growth

speaker: YORK
text_entry: The prince my brother hath outgrown me far.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: He hath, my lord.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And therefore is he idle?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: O, my fair cousin, I must not say so.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Then is he more beholding to you than I.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: He may command me as my sovereign;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: But you have power in me as in a kinsman.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: I pray you, uncle, give me this dagger.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: My dagger, little cousin? with all my heart.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: A beggar, brother?

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Of my kind uncle, that I know will give;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: And being but a toy, which is no grief to give.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: A greater gift than that I'll give my cousin.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: A greater gift! O, that's the sword to it.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: A gentle cousin, were it light enough.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: O, then, I see, you will part but with light gifts;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: In weightier things you'll say a beggar nay.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: It is too heavy for your grace to wear.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: I weigh it lightly, were it heavier.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: What, would you have my weapon, little lord?

speaker: YORK
text_entry: I would, that I might thank you as you call me.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: How?

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Little.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: My Lord of York will still be cross in talk:

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Uncle, your grace knows how to bear with him.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: You mean, to bear me, not to bear with me:

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Uncle, my brother mocks both you and me;

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Because that I am little, like an ape,

speaker: YORK
text_entry: He thinks that you should bear me on your shoulders.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: With what a sharp-provided wit he reasons!

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: To mitigate the scorn he gives his uncle,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: He prettily and aptly taunts himself:

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: So cunning and so young is wonderful.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: My lord, will't please you pass along?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Myself and my good cousin Buckingham

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Will to your mother, to entreat of her

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To meet you at the Tower and welcome you.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: What, will you go unto the Tower, my lord?

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: My lord protector needs will have it so.

speaker: YORK
text_entry: I shall not sleep in quiet at the Tower.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Why, what should you fear?

speaker: YORK
text_entry: Marry, my uncle Clarence' angry ghost:

speaker: YORK
text_entry: My grandam told me he was murdered there.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: I fear no uncles dead.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Nor none that live, I hope.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: An if they live, I hope I need not fear.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: But come, my lord; and with a heavy heart,

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: Thinking on them, go I unto the Tower.

speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
text_entry: A Sennet. Exeunt all but GLOUCESTER, BUCKINGHAM and CATESBY

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Think you, my lord, this little prating York

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Was not incensed by his subtle mother

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: To taunt and scorn you thus opprobriously?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: No doubt, no doubt; O, 'tis a parlous boy;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Bold, quick, ingenious, forward, capable

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: He is all the mother's, from the top to toe.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Well, let them rest. Come hither, Catesby.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Thou art sworn as deeply to effect what we intend

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: As closely to conceal what we impart:

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Thou know'st our reasons urged upon the way;

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: What think'st thou? is it not an easy matter

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: To make William Lord Hastings of our mind,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: For the instalment of this noble duke

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: In the seat royal of this famous isle?

speaker: CATESBY
text_entry: He for his father's sake so loves the prince,

speaker: CATESBY
text_entry: That he will not be won to aught against him.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: What think'st thou, then, of Stanley? what will he?

speaker: CATESBY
text_entry: He will do all in all as Hastings doth.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Well, then, no more but this: go, gentle Catesby,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: And, as it were far off sound thou Lord Hastings,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: How doth he stand affected to our purpose;

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: And summon him to-morrow to the Tower,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: To sit about the coronation.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: If thou dost find him tractable to us,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Encourage him, and show him all our reasons:

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: If he be leaden, icy-cold, unwilling,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Be thou so too; and so break off your talk,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: And give us notice of his inclination:

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: For we to-morrow hold divided councils,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Wherein thyself shalt highly be employ'd.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Commend me to Lord William: tell him, Catesby,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: His ancient knot of dangerous adversaries

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To-morrow are let blood at Pomfret-castle;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And bid my friend, for joy of this good news,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Give mistress Shore one gentle kiss the more.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Good Catesby, go, effect this business soundly.

speaker: CATESBY
text_entry: My good lords both, with all the heed I may.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Shall we hear from you, Catesby, ere we sleep?

speaker: CATESBY
text_entry: You shall, my lord.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: At Crosby Place, there shall you find us both.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Exit CATESBY

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Now, my lord, what shall we do, if we perceive

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Lord Hastings will not yield to our complots?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Chop off his head, man; somewhat we will do:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And, look, when I am king, claim thou of me

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: The earldom of Hereford, and the moveables

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Whereof the king my brother stood possess'd.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: I'll claim that promise at your grace's hands.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And look to have it yielded with all willingness.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Come, let us sup betimes, that afterwards

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: We may digest our complots in some form.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: SCENE II. Before Lord Hastings' house.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Enter a Messenger

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: What, ho! my lord!

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: [Within]  Who knocks at the door?

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: A messenger from the Lord Stanley.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Enter HASTINGS

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: What is't o'clock?

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Upon the stroke of four.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Cannot thy master sleep these tedious nights?

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: So it should seem by that I have to say.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: First, he commends him to your noble lordship.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: And then?

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: And then he sends you word

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: He dreamt to-night the boar had razed his helm:

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Besides, he says there are two councils held;

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: And that may be determined at the one

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: which may make you and him to rue at the other.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Therefore he sends to know your lordship's pleasure,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: If presently you will take horse with him,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: And with all speed post with him toward the north,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: To shun the danger that his soul divines.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Go, fellow, go, return unto thy lord;

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Bid him not fear the separated councils

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: His honour and myself are at the one,

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: And at the other is my servant Catesby

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Where nothing can proceed that toucheth us

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Whereof I shall not have intelligence.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Tell him his fears are shallow, wanting instance:

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: And for his dreams, I wonder he is so fond

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: To trust the mockery of unquiet slumbers

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: To fly the boar before the boar pursues,

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Were to incense the boar to follow us

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: And make pursuit where he did mean no chase.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Go, bid thy master rise and come to me

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: And we will both together to the Tower,

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Where, he shall see, the boar will use us kindly.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: My gracious lord, I'll tell him what you say.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Exit

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Enter CATESBY

speaker: CATESBY
text_entry: Many good morrows to my noble lord!

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Good morrow, Catesby; you are early stirring

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: What news, what news, in this our tottering state?

speaker: CATESBY
text_entry: It is a reeling world, indeed, my lord;

speaker: CATESBY
text_entry: And I believe twill never stand upright

speaker: CATESBY
text_entry: Tim Richard wear the garland of the realm.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: How! wear the garland! dost thou mean the crown?

speaker: CATESBY
text_entry: Ay, my good lord.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: I'll have this crown of mine cut from my shoulders

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Ere I will see the crown so foul misplaced.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: But canst thou guess that he doth aim at it?

speaker: CATESBY
text_entry: Ay, on my life; and hopes to find forward

speaker: CATESBY
text_entry: Upon his party for the gain thereof:

speaker: CATESBY
text_entry: And thereupon he sends you this good news,

speaker: CATESBY
text_entry: That this same very day your enemies,

speaker: CATESBY
text_entry: The kindred of the queen, must die at Pomfret.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Indeed, I am no mourner for that news,

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Because they have been still mine enemies:

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: But, that I'll give my voice on Richard's side,

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: To bar my master's heirs in true descent,

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: God knows I will not do it, to the death.

speaker: CATESBY
text_entry: God keep your lordship in that gracious mind!

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: But I shall laugh at this a twelve-month hence,

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: That they who brought me in my master's hate

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: I live to look upon their tragedy.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: I tell thee, Catesby--

speaker: CATESBY
text_entry: What, my lord?

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Ere a fortnight make me elder,

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: I'll send some packing that yet think not on it.

speaker: CATESBY
text_entry: 'Tis a vile thing to die, my gracious lord,

speaker: CATESBY
text_entry: When men are unprepared and look not for it.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: O monstrous, monstrous! and so falls it out

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: With Rivers, Vaughan, Grey: and so 'twill do

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: With some men else, who think themselves as safe

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: As thou and I; who, as thou know'st, are dear

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: To princely Richard and to Buckingham.

speaker: CATESBY
text_entry: The princes both make high account of you;

speaker: CATESBY
text_entry: Aside

speaker: CATESBY
text_entry: For they account his head upon the bridge.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: I know they do; and I have well deserved it.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Enter STANLEY

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Come on, come on; where is your boar-spear, man?

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Fear you the boar, and go so unprovided?

speaker: STANLEY
text_entry: My lord, good morrow; good morrow, Catesby:

speaker: STANLEY
text_entry: You may jest on, but, by the holy rood,

speaker: STANLEY
text_entry: I do not like these several councils, I.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: My lord,

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: I hold my life as dear as you do yours;

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: And never in my life, I do protest,

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Was it more precious to me than 'tis now:

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Think you, but that I know our state secure,

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: I would be so triumphant as I am?

speaker: STANLEY
text_entry: The lords at Pomfret, when they rode from London,

speaker: STANLEY
text_entry: Were jocund, and supposed their state was sure,

speaker: STANLEY
text_entry: And they indeed had no cause to mistrust;

speaker: STANLEY
text_entry: But yet, you see how soon the day o'ercast.

speaker: STANLEY
text_entry: This sudden stag of rancour I misdoubt:

speaker: STANLEY
text_entry: Pray God, I say, I prove a needless coward!

speaker: STANLEY
text_entry: What, shall we toward the Tower? the day is spent.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Come, come, have with you. Wot you what, my lord?

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: To-day the lords you talk of are beheaded.

speaker: LORD STANLEY
text_entry: They, for their truth, might better wear their heads

speaker: LORD STANLEY
text_entry: Than some that have accused them wear their hats.

speaker: LORD STANLEY
text_entry: But come, my lord, let us away.

speaker: LORD STANLEY
text_entry: Enter a Pursuivant

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Go on before; I'll talk with this good fellow.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Exeunt STANLEY and CATESBY

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: How now, sirrah! how goes the world with thee?

speaker: Pursuivant
text_entry: The better that your lordship please to ask.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: I tell thee, man, 'tis better with me now

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Than when I met thee last where now we meet:

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Then was I going prisoner to the Tower,

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: By the suggestion of the queen's allies;

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: But now, I tell thee--keep it to thyself--

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: This day those enemies are put to death,

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: And I in better state than e'er I was.

speaker: Pursuivant
text_entry: God hold it, to your honour's good content!

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Gramercy, fellow: there, drink that for me.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Throws him his purse

speaker: Pursuivant
text_entry: God save your lordship!

speaker: Pursuivant
text_entry: Exit

speaker: Pursuivant
text_entry: Enter a Priest

speaker: Priest
text_entry: Well met, my lord; I am glad to see your honour.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: I thank thee, good Sir John, with all my heart.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: I am in your debt for your last exercise;

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Come the next Sabbath, and I will content you.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: He whispers in his ear

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Enter BUCKINGHAM

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: What, talking with a priest, lord chamberlain?

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Your friends at Pomfret, they do need the priest;

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Your honour hath no shriving work in hand.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Good faith, and when I met this holy man,

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Those men you talk of came into my mind.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: What, go you toward the Tower?

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: I do, my lord; but long I shall not stay

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: I shall return before your lordship thence.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: 'Tis like enough, for I stay dinner there.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: [Aside]  And supper too, although thou know'st it not.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Come, will you go?

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: I'll wait upon your lordship.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: SCENE III. Pomfret Castle.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Enter RATCLIFF, with halberds, carrying RIVERS, GREY, and VAUGHAN to death

speaker: RATCLIFF
text_entry: Come, bring forth the prisoners.

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: Sir Richard Ratcliff, let me tell thee this:

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: To-day shalt thou behold a subject die

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: For truth, for duty, and for loyalty.

speaker: GREY
text_entry: God keep the prince from all the pack of you!

speaker: GREY
text_entry: A knot you are of damned blood-suckers!

speaker: VAUGHAN
text_entry: You live that shall cry woe for this after.

speaker: RATCLIFF
text_entry: Dispatch; the limit of your lives is out.

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: O Pomfret, Pomfret! O thou bloody prison,

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: Fatal and ominous to noble peers!

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: Within the guilty closure of thy walls

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: Richard the second here was hack'd to death;

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: And, for more slander to thy dismal seat,

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: We give thee up our guiltless blood to drink.

speaker: GREY
text_entry: Now Margaret's curse is fall'n upon our heads,

speaker: GREY
text_entry: For standing by when Richard stabb'd her son.

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: Then cursed she Hastings, then cursed she Buckingham,

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: Then cursed she Richard. O, remember, God

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: To hear her prayers for them, as now for us

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: And for my sister and her princely sons,

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: Be satisfied, dear God, with our true blood,

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: Which, as thou know'st, unjustly must be spilt.

speaker: RATCLIFF
text_entry: Make haste; the hour of death is expiate.

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: Come, Grey, come, Vaughan, let us all embrace:

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: And take our leave, until we meet in heaven.

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: SCENE IV. The Tower of London.

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: Enter BUCKINGHAM, DERBY, HASTINGS, the BISHOP OF  ELY, RATCLIFF, LOVEL, with others, and take their seats at a table

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: My lords, at once: the cause why we are met

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Is, to determine of the coronation.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: In God's name, speak: when is the royal day?

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Are all things fitting for that royal time?

speaker: DERBY
text_entry: It is, and wants but nomination.

speaker: BISHOP OF ELY
text_entry: To-morrow, then, I judge a happy day.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Who knows the lord protector's mind herein?

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Who is most inward with the royal duke?

speaker: BISHOP OF ELY
text_entry: Your grace, we think, should soonest know his mind.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Who, I, my lord I we know each other's faces,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: But for our hearts, he knows no more of mine,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Than I of yours;

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Nor I no more of his, than you of mine.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Lord Hastings, you and he are near in love.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: I thank his grace, I know he loves me well;

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: But, for his purpose in the coronation.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: I have not sounded him, nor he deliver'd

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: His gracious pleasure any way therein:

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: But you, my noble lords, may name the time;

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: And in the duke's behalf I'll give my voice,

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Which, I presume, he'll take in gentle part.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Enter GLOUCESTER

speaker: BISHOP OF ELY
text_entry: Now in good time, here comes the duke himself.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: My noble lords and cousins all, good morrow.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I have been long a sleeper; but, I hope,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: My absence doth neglect no great designs,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Which by my presence might have been concluded.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Had not you come upon your cue, my lord

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: William Lord Hastings had pronounced your part,--

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: I mean, your voice,--for crowning of the king.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Than my Lord Hastings no man might be bolder;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: His lordship knows me well, and loves me well.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: I thank your grace.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: My lord of Ely!

speaker: BISHOP OF ELY
text_entry: My lord?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: When I was last in Holborn,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I saw good strawberries in your garden there

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I do beseech you send for some of them.

speaker: BISHOP OF ELY
text_entry: Marry, and will, my lord, with all my heart.

speaker: BISHOP OF ELY
text_entry: Exit

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Cousin of Buckingham, a word with you.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Drawing him aside

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Catesby hath sounded Hastings in our business,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And finds the testy gentleman so hot,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: As he will lose his head ere give consent

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: His master's son, as worshipful as he terms it,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Shall lose the royalty of England's throne.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Withdraw you hence, my lord, I'll follow you.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Exit GLOUCESTER, BUCKINGHAM following

speaker: DERBY
text_entry: We have not yet set down this day of triumph.

speaker: DERBY
text_entry: To-morrow, in mine opinion, is too sudden;

speaker: DERBY
text_entry: For I myself am not so well provided

speaker: DERBY
text_entry: As else I would be, were the day prolong'd.

speaker: DERBY
text_entry: Re-enter BISHOP OF ELY

speaker: BISHOP OF ELY
text_entry: Where is my lord protector? I have sent for these

speaker: BISHOP OF ELY
text_entry: strawberries.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: His grace looks cheerfully and smooth to-day;

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: There's some conceit or other likes him well,

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: When he doth bid good morrow with such a spirit.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: I think there's never a man in Christendom

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: That can less hide his love or hate than he;

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: For by his face straight shall you know his heart.

speaker: DERBY
text_entry: What of his heart perceive you in his face

speaker: DERBY
text_entry: By any likelihood he show'd to-day?

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Marry, that with no man here he is offended;

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: For, were he, he had shown it in his looks.

speaker: DERBY
text_entry: I pray God he be not, I say.

speaker: DERBY
text_entry: Re-enter GLOUCESTER and BUCKINGHAM

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I pray you all, tell me what they deserve

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: That do conspire my death with devilish plots

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Of damned witchcraft, and that have prevail'd

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Upon my body with their hellish charms?

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: The tender love I bear your grace, my lord,

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Makes me most forward in this noble presence

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: To doom the offenders, whatsoever they be

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: I say, my lord, they have deserved death.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Then be your eyes the witness of this ill:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: See how I am bewitch'd; behold mine arm

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Is, like a blasted sapling, wither'd up:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And this is Edward's wife, that monstrous witch,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Consorted with that harlot strumpet Shore,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: That by their witchcraft thus have marked me.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: If they have done this thing, my gracious lord--

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: If I thou protector of this damned strumpet--

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Tellest thou me of 'ifs'?  Thou art a traitor:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Off with his head! Now, by Saint Paul I swear,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I will not dine until I see the same.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Lovel and Ratcliff, look that it be done:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: The rest, that love me, rise and follow me.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Exeunt all but HASTINGS, RATCLIFF, and LOVEL

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Woe, woe for England! not a whit for me;

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: For I, too fond, might have prevented this.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Stanley did dream the boar did raze his helm;

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: But I disdain'd it, and did scorn to fly:

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Three times to-day my foot-cloth horse did stumble,

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: And startled, when he look'd upon the Tower,

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: As loath to bear me to the slaughter-house.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: O, now I want the priest that spake to me:

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: I now repent I told the pursuivant

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: As 'twere triumphing at mine enemies,

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: How they at Pomfret bloodily were butcher'd,

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: And I myself secure in grace and favour.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: O Margaret, Margaret, now thy heavy curse

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Is lighted on poor Hastings' wretched head!

speaker: RATCLIFF
text_entry: Dispatch, my lord; the duke would be at dinner:

speaker: RATCLIFF
text_entry: Make a short shrift; he longs to see your head.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: O momentary grace of mortal men,

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Which we more hunt for than the grace of God!

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Who builds his hopes in air of your good looks,

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Lives like a drunken sailor on a mast,

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Ready, with every nod, to tumble down

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Into the fatal bowels of the deep.

speaker: LOVEL
text_entry: Come, come, dispatch; 'tis bootless to exclaim.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: O bloody Richard! miserable England!

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: I prophesy the fearful'st time to thee

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: That ever wretched age hath look'd upon.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Come, lead me to the block; bear him my head.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: They smile at me that shortly shall be dead.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: SCENE V. The Tower-walls.

speaker: HASTINGS
text_entry: Enter GLOUCESTER and BUCKINGHAM, in rotten armour, marvellous ill-favoured

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Come, cousin, canst thou quake, and change thy colour,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Murder thy breath in the middle of a word,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And then begin again, and stop again,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: As if thou wert distraught and mad with terror?

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Tut, I can counterfeit the deep tragedian;

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Speak and look back, and pry on every side,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Tremble and start at wagging of a straw,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Intending deep suspicion: ghastly looks

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Are at my service, like enforced smiles;

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: And both are ready in their offices,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: At any time, to grace my stratagems.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: But what, is Catesby gone?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: He is; and, see, he brings the mayor along.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Enter the Lord Mayor and CATESBY

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Lord mayor,--

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Look to the drawbridge there!

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Hark! a drum.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Catesby, o'erlook the walls.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Lord mayor, the reason we have sent--

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Look back, defend thee, here are enemies.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: God and our innocency defend and guard us!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Be patient, they are friends, Ratcliff and Lovel.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Enter LOVEL and RATCLIFF, with HASTINGS' head

speaker: LOVEL
text_entry: Here is the head of that ignoble traitor,

speaker: LOVEL
text_entry: The dangerous and unsuspected Hastings.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: So dear I loved the man, that I must weep.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I took him for the plainest harmless creature

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: That breathed upon this earth a Christian;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Made him my book wherein my soul recorded

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: The history of all her secret thoughts:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: So smooth he daub'd his vice with show of virtue,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: That, his apparent open guilt omitted,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I mean, his conversation with Shore's wife,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: He lived from all attainder of suspect.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Well, well, he was the covert'st shelter'd traitor

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: That ever lived.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Would you imagine, or almost believe,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Were't not that, by great preservation,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: We live to tell it you, the subtle traitor

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: This day had plotted, in the council-house

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: To murder me and my good Lord of Gloucester?

speaker: Lord Mayor
text_entry: What, had he so?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: What, think You we are Turks or infidels?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Or that we would, against the form of law,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Proceed thus rashly to the villain's death,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: But that the extreme peril of the case,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: The peace of England and our persons' safety,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Enforced us to this execution?

speaker: Lord Mayor
text_entry: Now, fair befall you! he deserved his death;

speaker: Lord Mayor
text_entry: And you my good lords, both have well proceeded,

speaker: Lord Mayor
text_entry: To warn false traitors from the like attempts.

speaker: Lord Mayor
text_entry: I never look'd for better at his hands,

speaker: Lord Mayor
text_entry: After he once fell in with Mistress Shore.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Yet had not we determined he should die,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Until your lordship came to see his death;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Which now the loving haste of these our friends,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Somewhat against our meaning, have prevented:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Because, my lord, we would have had you heard

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: The traitor speak, and timorously confess

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: The manner and the purpose of his treason;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: That you might well have signified the same

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Unto the citizens, who haply may

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Misconstrue us in him and wail his death.

speaker: Lord Mayor
text_entry: But, my good lord, your grace's word shall serve,

speaker: Lord Mayor
text_entry: As well as I had seen and heard him speak

speaker: Lord Mayor
text_entry: And doubt you not, right noble princes both,

speaker: Lord Mayor
text_entry: But I'll acquaint our duteous citizens

speaker: Lord Mayor
text_entry: With all your just proceedings in this cause.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And to that end we wish'd your lord-ship here,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To avoid the carping censures of the world.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: But since you come too late of our intents,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Yet witness what you hear we did intend:

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: And so, my good lord mayor, we bid farewell.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Exit Lord Mayor

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Go, after, after, cousin Buckingham.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: The mayor towards Guildhall hies him in all post:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: There, at your meet'st advantage of the time,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Infer the bastardy of Edward's children:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Tell them how Edward put to death a citizen,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Only for saying he would make his son

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Heir to the crown; meaning indeed his house,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Which, by the sign thereof was termed so.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Moreover, urge his hateful luxury

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And bestial appetite in change of lust;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Which stretched to their servants, daughters, wives,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Even where his lustful eye or savage heart,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Without control, listed to make his prey.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Nay, for a need, thus far come near my person:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
