text_entry: Tell them, when that my mother went with child

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Of that unsatiate Edward, noble York

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: My princely father then had wars in France

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And, by just computation of the time,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Found that the issue was not his begot;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Which well appeared in his lineaments,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Being nothing like the noble duke my father:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: But touch this sparingly, as 'twere far off,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Because you know, my lord, my mother lives.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Fear not, my lord, I'll play the orator

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: As if the golden fee for which I plead

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Were for myself: and so, my lord, adieu.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: If you thrive well, bring them to Baynard's Castle;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Where you shall find me well accompanied

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: With reverend fathers and well-learned bishops.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: I go: and towards three or four o'clock

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Look for the news that the Guildhall affords.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Exit BUCKINGHAM

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Go, Lovel, with all speed to Doctor Shaw;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To CATESBY

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Go thou to Friar Penker; bid them both

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Meet me within this hour at Baynard's Castle.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Exeunt all but GLOUCESTER

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Now will I in, to take some privy order,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To draw the brats of Clarence out of sight;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And to give notice, that no manner of person

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: At any time have recourse unto the princes.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Exit

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: SCENE VI. The same.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Enter a Scrivener, with a paper in his hand

speaker: Scrivener
text_entry: This is the indictment of the good Lord Hastings;

speaker: Scrivener
text_entry: Which in a set hand fairly is engross'd,

speaker: Scrivener
text_entry: That it may be this day read over in Paul's.

speaker: Scrivener
text_entry: And mark how well the sequel hangs together:

speaker: Scrivener
text_entry: Eleven hours I spent to write it over,

speaker: Scrivener
text_entry: For yesternight by Catesby was it brought me;

speaker: Scrivener
text_entry: The precedent was full as long a-doing:

speaker: Scrivener
text_entry: And yet within these five hours lived Lord Hastings,

speaker: Scrivener
text_entry: Untainted, unexamined, free, at liberty

speaker: Scrivener
text_entry: Here's a good world the while! Why who's so gross,

speaker: Scrivener
text_entry: That seeth not this palpable device?

speaker: Scrivener
text_entry: Yet who's so blind, but says he sees it not?

speaker: Scrivener
text_entry: Bad is the world; and all will come to nought,

speaker: Scrivener
text_entry: When such bad dealings must be seen in thought.

speaker: Scrivener
text_entry: Exit

speaker: Scrivener
text_entry: SCENE VII. Baynard's Castle.

speaker: Scrivener
text_entry: Enter GLOUCESTER and BUCKINGHAM, at several doors

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: How now, my lord, what say the citizens?

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Now, by the holy mother of our Lord,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: The citizens are mum and speak not a word.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Touch'd you the bastardy of Edward's children?

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: I did; with his contract with Lady Lucy,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: And his contract by deputy in France;

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: The insatiate greediness of his desires,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: And his enforcement of the city wives;

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: His tyranny for trifles; his own bastardy,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: As being got, your father then in France,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: His resemblance, being not like the duke;

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Withal I did infer your lineaments,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Being the right idea of your father,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Both in your form and nobleness of mind;

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Laid open all your victories in Scotland,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Your dicipline in war, wisdom in peace,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Your bounty, virtue, fair humility:

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Indeed, left nothing fitting for the purpose

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Untouch'd, or slightly handled, in discourse

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: And when mine oratory grew to an end

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: I bid them that did love their country's good

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Cry 'God save Richard, England's royal king!'

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Ah! and did they so?

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: No, so God help me, they spake not a word;

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: But, like dumb statues or breathing stones,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Gazed each on other, and look'd deadly pale.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Which when I saw, I reprehended them;

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: And ask'd the mayor what meant this wilful silence:

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: His answer was, the people were not wont

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: To be spoke to but by the recorder.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Then he was urged to tell my tale again,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: 'Thus saith the duke, thus hath the duke inferr'd;'

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: But nothing spake in warrant from himself.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: When he had done, some followers of mine own,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: At the lower end of the hall, hurl'd up their caps,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: And some ten voices cried 'God save King Richard!'

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: And thus I took the vantage of those few,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: 'Thanks, gentle citizens and friends,' quoth I;

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: 'This general applause and loving shout

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Argues your wisdoms and your love to Richard:'

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: And even here brake off, and came away.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: What tongueless blocks were they! would not they speak?

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: No, by my troth, my lord.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Will not the mayor then and his brethren come?

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: The mayor is here at hand: intend some fear;

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Be not you spoke with, but by mighty suit:

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: And look you get a prayer-book in your hand,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: And stand betwixt two churchmen, good my lord;

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: For on that ground I'll build a holy descant:

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: And be not easily won to our request:

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Play the maid's part, still answer nay, and take it.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I go; and if you plead as well for them

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: As I can say nay to thee for myself,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: No doubt well bring it to a happy issue.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Go, go, up to the leads; the lord mayor knocks.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Exit GLOUCESTER

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Enter the Lord Mayor and Citizens

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Welcome my lord; I dance attendance here;

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: I think the duke will not be spoke withal.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Enter CATESBY

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Here comes his servant: how now, Catesby,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: What says he?

speaker: CATESBY
text_entry: My lord: he doth entreat your grace;

speaker: CATESBY
text_entry: To visit him to-morrow or next day:

speaker: CATESBY
text_entry: He is within, with two right reverend fathers,

speaker: CATESBY
text_entry: Divinely bent to meditation;

speaker: CATESBY
text_entry: And no worldly suit would he be moved,

speaker: CATESBY
text_entry: To draw him from his holy exercise.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Return, good Catesby, to thy lord again;

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Tell him, myself, the mayor and citizens,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: In deep designs and matters of great moment,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: No less importing than our general good,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Are come to have some conference with his grace.

speaker: CATESBY
text_entry: I'll tell him what you say, my lord.

speaker: CATESBY
text_entry: Exit

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Ah, ha, my lord, this prince is not an Edward!

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: He is not lolling on a lewd day-bed,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: But on his knees at meditation;

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Not dallying with a brace of courtezans,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: But meditating with two deep divines;

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Not sleeping, to engross his idle body,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: But praying, to enrich his watchful soul:

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Happy were England, would this gracious prince

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Take on himself the sovereignty thereof:

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: But, sure, I fear, we shall ne'er win him to it.

speaker: Lord Mayor
text_entry: Marry, God forbid his grace should say us nay!

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: I fear he will.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Re-enter CATESBY

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: How now, Catesby, what says your lord?

speaker: CATESBY
text_entry: My lord,

speaker: CATESBY
text_entry: He wonders to what end you have assembled

speaker: CATESBY
text_entry: Such troops of citizens to speak with him,

speaker: CATESBY
text_entry: His grace not being warn'd thereof before:

speaker: CATESBY
text_entry: My lord, he fears you mean no good to him.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Sorry I am my noble cousin should

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Suspect me, that I mean no good to him:

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: By heaven, I come in perfect love to him;

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: And so once more return and tell his grace.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Exit CATESBY

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: When holy and devout religious men

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Are at their beads, 'tis hard to draw them thence,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: So sweet is zealous contemplation.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Enter GLOUCESTER aloft, between two Bishops. CATESBY returns

speaker: Lord Mayor
text_entry: See, where he stands between two clergymen!

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Two props of virtue for a Christian prince,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: To stay him from the fall of vanity:

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: And, see, a book of prayer in his hand,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: True ornaments to know a holy man.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Famous Plantagenet, most gracious prince,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Lend favourable ears to our request;

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: And pardon us the interruption

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Of thy devotion and right Christian zeal.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: My lord, there needs no such apology:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I rather do beseech you pardon me,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Who, earnest in the service of my God,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Neglect the visitation of my friends.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: But, leaving this, what is your grace's pleasure?

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Even that, I hope, which pleaseth God above,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: And all good men of this ungovern'd isle.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I do suspect I have done some offence

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: That seems disgracious in the city's eyes,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And that you come to reprehend my ignorance.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: You have, my lord: would it might please your grace,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: At our entreaties, to amend that fault!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Else wherefore breathe I in a Christian land?

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Then know, it is your fault that you resign

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: The supreme seat, the throne majestical,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: The scepter'd office of your ancestors,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Your state of fortune and your due of birth,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: The lineal glory of your royal house,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: To the corruption of a blemished stock:

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Whilst, in the mildness of your sleepy thoughts,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Which here we waken to our country's good,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: This noble isle doth want her proper limbs;

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Her face defaced with scars of infamy,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Her royal stock graft with ignoble plants,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: And almost shoulder'd in the swallowing gulf

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Of blind forgetfulness and dark oblivion.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Which to recure, we heartily solicit

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Your gracious self to take on you the charge

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: And kingly government of this your land,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Not as protector, steward, substitute,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Or lowly factor for another's gain;

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: But as successively from blood to blood,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Your right of birth, your empery, your own.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: For this, consorted with the citizens,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Your very worshipful and loving friends,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: And by their vehement instigation,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: In this just suit come I to move your grace.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I know not whether to depart in silence,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Or bitterly to speak in your reproof.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Best fitteth my degree or your condition

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: If not to answer, you might haply think

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Tongue-tied ambition, not replying, yielded

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To bear the golden yoke of sovereignty,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Which fondly you would here impose on me;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: If to reprove you for this suit of yours,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: So season'd with your faithful love to me.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Then, on the other side, I cheque'd my friends.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Therefore, to speak, and to avoid the first,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And then, in speaking, not to incur the last,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Definitively thus I answer you.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Your love deserves my thanks; but my desert

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Unmeritable shuns your high request.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: First if all obstacles were cut away,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And that my path were even to the crown,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: As my ripe revenue and due by birth

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Yet so much is my poverty of spirit,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: So mighty and so many my defects,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: As I had rather hide me from my greatness,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Being a bark to brook no mighty sea,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Than in my greatness covet to be hid,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And in the vapour of my glory smother'd.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: But, God be thank'd, there's no need of me,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And much I need to help you, if need were;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: The royal tree hath left us royal fruit,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Which, mellow'd by the stealing hours of time,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Will well become the seat of majesty,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: And make, no doubt, us happy by his reign.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: On him I lay what you would lay on me,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: The right and fortune of his happy stars;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Which God defend that I should wring from him!

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: My lord, this argues conscience in your grace;

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: But the respects thereof are nice and trivial,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: All circumstances well considered.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: You say that Edward is your brother's son:

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: So say we too, but not by Edward's wife;

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: For first he was contract to Lady Lucy--

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Your mother lives a witness to that vow--

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: And afterward by substitute betroth'd

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: To Bona, sister to the King of France.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: These both put by a poor petitioner,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: A care-crazed mother of a many children,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: A beauty-waning and distressed widow,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Even in the afternoon of her best days,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Made prize and purchase of his lustful eye,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Seduced the pitch and height of all his thoughts

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: To base declension and loathed bigamy

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: By her, in his unlawful bed, he got

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: This Edward, whom our manners term the prince.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: More bitterly could I expostulate,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Save that, for reverence to some alive,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: I give a sparing limit to my tongue.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Then, good my lord, take to your royal self

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: This proffer'd benefit of dignity;

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: If non to bless us and the land withal,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Yet to draw forth your noble ancestry

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: From the corruption of abusing times,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Unto a lineal true-derived course.

speaker: Lord Mayor
text_entry: Do, good my lord, your citizens entreat you.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Refuse not, mighty lord, this proffer'd love.

speaker: CATESBY
text_entry: O, make them joyful, grant their lawful suit!

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Alas, why would you heap these cares on me?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I am unfit for state and majesty;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I do beseech you, take it not amiss;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I cannot nor I will not yield to you.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: If you refuse it,--as, in love and zeal,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Loath to depose the child, Your brother's son;

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: As well we know your tenderness of heart

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: And gentle, kind, effeminate remorse,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Which we have noted in you to your kin,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: And egally indeed to all estates,--

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Yet whether you accept our suit or no,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Your brother's son shall never reign our king;

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: But we will plant some other in the throne,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: To the disgrace and downfall of your house:

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: And in this resolution here we leave you.--

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Come, citizens: 'zounds! I'll entreat no more.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: O, do not swear, my lord of Buckingham.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Exit BUCKINGHAM with the Citizens

speaker: CATESBY
text_entry: Call them again, my lord, and accept their suit.

speaker: ANOTHER
text_entry: Do, good my lord, lest all the land do rue it.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Would you enforce me to a world of care?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Well, call them again. I am not made of stone,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: But penetrable to your. kind entreats,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Albeit against my conscience and my soul.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Re-enter BUCKINGHAM and the rest

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Cousin of Buckingham, and you sage, grave men,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Since you will buckle fortune on my back,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: To bear her burthen, whether I will or no,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: I must have patience to endure the load:

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: But if black scandal or foul-faced reproach

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Attend the sequel of your imposition,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Your mere enforcement shall acquittance me

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: From all the impure blots and stains thereof;

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: For God he knows, and you may partly see,

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: How far I am from the desire thereof.

speaker: Lord Mayor
text_entry: God bless your grace! we see it, and will say it.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: In saying so, you shall but say the truth.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Then I salute you with this kingly title:

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Long live Richard, England's royal king!

speaker: Citizens
text_entry: Amen.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: To-morrow will it please you to be crown'd?

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Even when you please, since you will have it so.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: To-morrow, then, we will attend your grace:

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: And so most joyfully we take our leave.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Come, let us to our holy task again.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Farewell, good cousin; farewell, gentle friends.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: ACT IV

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: SCENE I. Before the Tower.

speaker: GLOUCESTER
text_entry: Enter, on one side, QUEEN ELIZABETH, DUCHESS OF  YORK, and DORSET; on the other, ANNE, Duchess of  Gloucester, leading Lady Margaret Plantagenet, CLARENCE's young Daughter

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Who m eets us here?  my niece Plantagenet

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Led in the hand of her kind aunt of Gloucester?

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Now, for my life, she's wandering to the Tower,

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: On pure heart's love to greet the tender princes.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Daughter, well met.

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: God give your graces both

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: A happy and a joyful time of day!

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: As much to you, good sister! Whither away?

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: No farther than the Tower; and, as I guess,

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Upon the like devotion as yourselves,

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: To gratulate the gentle princes there.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Kind sister, thanks: we'll enter all together.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Enter BRAKENBURY

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: And, in good time, here the lieutenant comes.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Master lieutenant, pray you, by your leave,

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: How doth the prince, and my young son of York?

speaker: BRAKENBURY
text_entry: Right well, dear madam. By your patience,

speaker: BRAKENBURY
text_entry: I may not suffer you to visit them;

speaker: BRAKENBURY
text_entry: The king hath straitly charged the contrary.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: The king! why, who's that?

speaker: BRAKENBURY
text_entry: I cry you mercy: I mean the lord protector.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: The Lord protect him from that kingly title!

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Hath he set bounds betwixt their love and me?

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: I am their mother; who should keep me from them?

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: I am their fathers mother; I will see them.

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Their aunt I am in law, in love their mother:

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Then bring me to their sights; I'll bear thy blame

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: And take thy office from thee, on my peril.

speaker: BRAKENBURY
text_entry: No, madam, no; I may not leave it so:

speaker: BRAKENBURY
text_entry: I am bound by oath, and therefore pardon me.

speaker: BRAKENBURY
text_entry: Exit

speaker: BRAKENBURY
text_entry: Enter LORD STANLEY

speaker: LORD STANLEY
text_entry: Let me but meet you, ladies, one hour hence,

speaker: LORD STANLEY
text_entry: And I'll salute your grace of York as mother,

speaker: LORD STANLEY
text_entry: And reverend looker on, of two fair queens.

speaker: LORD STANLEY
text_entry: To LADY ANNE

speaker: LORD STANLEY
text_entry: Come, madam, you must straight to Westminster,

speaker: LORD STANLEY
text_entry: There to be crowned Richard's royal queen.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: O, cut my lace in sunder, that my pent heart

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: May have some scope to beat, or else I swoon

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: With this dead-killing news!

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Despiteful tidings! O unpleasing news!

speaker: DORSET
text_entry: Be of good cheer: mother, how fares your grace?

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: O Dorset, speak not to me, get thee hence!

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Death and destruction dog thee at the heels;

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Thy mother's name is ominous to children.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: If thou wilt outstrip death, go cross the seas,

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: And live with Richmond, from the reach of hell

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Go, hie thee, hie thee from this slaughter-house,

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Lest thou increase the number of the dead;

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: And make me die the thrall of Margaret's curse,

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Nor mother, wife, nor England's counted queen.

speaker: LORD STANLEY
text_entry: Full of wise care is this your counsel, madam.

speaker: LORD STANLEY
text_entry: Take all the swift advantage of the hours;

speaker: LORD STANLEY
text_entry: You shall have letters from me to my son

speaker: LORD STANLEY
text_entry: To meet you on the way, and welcome you.

speaker: LORD STANLEY
text_entry: Be not ta'en tardy by unwise delay.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: O ill-dispersing wind of misery!

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: O my accursed womb, the bed of death!

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: A cockatrice hast thou hatch'd to the world,

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Whose unavoided eye is murderous.

speaker: LORD STANLEY
text_entry: Come, madam, come; I in all haste was sent.

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: And I in all unwillingness will go.

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: I would to God that the inclusive verge

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Of golden metal that must round my brow

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Were red-hot steel, to sear me to the brain!

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Anointed let me be with deadly venom,

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: And die, ere men can say, God save the queen!

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Go, go, poor soul, I envy not thy glory

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: To feed my humour, wish thyself no harm.

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: No! why?  When he that is my husband now

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Came to me, as I follow'd Henry's corse,

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: When scarce the blood was well wash'd from his hands

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Which issued from my other angel husband

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: And that dead saint which then I weeping follow'd;

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: O, when, I say, I look'd on Richard's face,

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: This was my wish: 'Be thou,' quoth I, ' accursed,

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: For making me, so young, so old a widow!

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: And, when thou wed'st, let sorrow haunt thy bed;

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: And be thy wife--if any be so mad--

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: As miserable by the life of thee

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: As thou hast made me by my dear lord's death!

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Lo, ere I can repeat this curse again,

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Even in so short a space, my woman's heart

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Grossly grew captive to his honey words

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: And proved the subject of my own soul's curse,

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Which ever since hath kept my eyes from rest;

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: For never yet one hour in his bed

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Have I enjoy'd the golden dew of sleep,

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: But have been waked by his timorous dreams.

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Besides, he hates me for my father Warwick;

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: And will, no doubt, shortly be rid of me.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Poor heart, adieu! I pity thy complaining.

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: No more than from my soul I mourn for yours.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Farewell, thou woful welcomer of glory!

speaker: LADY ANNE
text_entry: Adieu, poor soul, that takest thy leave of it!

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: [To DORSET]

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Go thou to Richmond, and good fortune guide thee!

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: To LADY ANNE

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Go thou to Richard, and good angels guard thee!

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: To QUEEN ELIZABETH

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Go thou to sanctuary, and good thoughts possess thee!

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: I to my grave, where peace and rest lie with me!

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Eighty odd years of sorrow have I seen,

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: And each hour's joy wrecked with a week of teen.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Stay, yet look back with me unto the Tower.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Pity, you ancient stones, those tender babes

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Whom envy hath immured within your walls!

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Rough cradle for such little pretty ones!

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Rude ragged nurse, old sullen playfellow

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: For tender princes, use my babies well!

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: So foolish sorrow bids your stones farewell.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: SCENE II. London. The palace.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Sennet. Enter KING RICHARD III, in pomp, crowned; BUCKINGHAM, CATESBY, a page, and others

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Stand all apart Cousin of Buckingham!

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: My gracious sovereign?

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Give me thy hand.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Here he ascendeth his throne

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Thus high, by thy advice

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: And thy assistance, is King Richard seated;

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: But shall we wear these honours for a day?

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Or shall they last, and we rejoice in them?

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Still live they and for ever may they last!

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: O Buckingham, now do I play the touch,

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: To try if thou be current gold indeed

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Young Edward lives: think now what I would say.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Say on, my loving lord.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Why, Buckingham, I say, I would be king,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Why, so you are, my thrice renowned liege.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Ha! am I king? 'tis so: but Edward lives.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: True, noble prince.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: O bitter consequence,

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: That Edward still should live! 'True, noble prince!'

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Cousin, thou wert not wont to be so dull:

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Shall I be plain? I wish the bastards dead;

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: And I would have it suddenly perform'd.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: What sayest thou? speak suddenly; be brief.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Your grace may do your pleasure.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Tut, tut, thou art all ice, thy kindness freezeth:

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Say, have I thy consent that they shall die?

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Give me some breath, some little pause, my lord

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Before I positively herein:

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: I will resolve your grace immediately.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Exit

speaker: CATESBY
text_entry: [Aside to a stander by]

speaker: CATESBY
text_entry: The king is angry: see, he bites the lip.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: I will converse with iron-witted fools

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: And unrespective boys: none are for me

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: That look into me with considerate eyes:

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: High-reaching Buckingham grows circumspect.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Boy!

speaker: Page
text_entry: My lord?

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Know'st thou not any whom corrupting gold

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Would tempt unto a close exploit of death?

speaker: Page
text_entry: My lord, I know a discontented gentleman,

speaker: Page
text_entry: Whose humble means match not his haughty mind:

speaker: Page
text_entry: Gold were as good as twenty orators,

speaker: Page
text_entry: And will, no doubt, tempt him to any thing.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: What is his name?

speaker: Page
text_entry: His name, my lord, is Tyrrel.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: I partly know the man: go, call him hither.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Exit Page

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: The deep-revolving witty Buckingham

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: No more shall be the neighbour to my counsel:

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Hath he so long held out with me untired,

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: And stops he now for breath?

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Enter STANLEY

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: How now! what news with you?

speaker: STANLEY
text_entry: My lord, I hear the Marquis Dorset's fled

speaker: STANLEY
text_entry: To Richmond, in those parts beyond the sea

speaker: STANLEY
text_entry: Where he abides.

speaker: STANLEY
text_entry: Stands apart

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Catesby!

speaker: CATESBY
text_entry: My lord?

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Rumour it abroad

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: That Anne, my wife, is sick and like to die:

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: I will take order for her keeping close.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Inquire me out some mean-born gentleman,

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Whom I will marry straight to Clarence' daughter:

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: The boy is foolish, and I fear not him.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Look, how thou dream'st! I say again, give out

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: That Anne my wife is sick and like to die:

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: About it; for it stands me much upon,

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: To stop all hopes whose growth may damage me.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Exit CATESBY

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: I must be married to my brother's daughter,

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Or else my kingdom stands on brittle glass.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Murder her brothers, and then marry her!

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Uncertain way of gain! But I am in

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: So far in blood that sin will pluck on sin:

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Tear-falling pity dwells not in this eye.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Re-enter Page, with TYRREL

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Is thy name Tyrrel?

speaker: TYRREL
text_entry: James Tyrrel, and your most obedient subject.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Art thou, indeed?

speaker: TYRREL
text_entry: Prove me, my gracious sovereign.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Darest thou resolve to kill a friend of mine?

speaker: TYRREL
text_entry: Ay, my lord;

speaker: TYRREL
text_entry: But I had rather kill two enemies.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Why, there thou hast it: two deep enemies,

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Foes to my rest and my sweet sleep's disturbers

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Are they that I would have thee deal upon:

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Tyrrel, I mean those bastards in the Tower.

speaker: TYRREL
text_entry: Let me have open means to come to them,

speaker: TYRREL
text_entry: And soon I'll rid you from the fear of them.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Thou sing'st sweet music. Hark, come hither, Tyrrel

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Go, by this token: rise, and lend thine ear:

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Whispers

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: There is no more but so: say it is done,

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: And I will love thee, and prefer thee too.

speaker: TYRREL
text_entry: 'Tis done, my gracious lord.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Shall we hear from thee, Tyrrel, ere we sleep?

speaker: TYRREL
text_entry: Ye shall, my Lord.

speaker: TYRREL
text_entry: Exit

speaker: TYRREL
text_entry: Re-enter BUCKINGHAM

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: My Lord, I have consider'd in my mind

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: The late demand that you did sound me in.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Well, let that pass. Dorset is fled to Richmond.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: I hear that news, my lord.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Stanley, he is your wife's son well, look to it.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: My lord, I claim your gift, my due by promise,

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: For which your honour and your faith is pawn'd;

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: The earldom of Hereford and the moveables

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: The which you promised I should possess.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Stanley, look to your wife; if she convey

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Letters to Richmond, you shall answer it.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: What says your highness to my just demand?

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: As I remember, Henry the Sixth

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Did prophesy that Richmond should be king,

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: When Richmond was a little peevish boy.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: A king, perhaps, perhaps,--

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: My lord!

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: How chance the prophet could not at that time

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Have told me, I being by, that I should kill him?

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: My lord, your promise for the earldom,--

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Richmond! When last I was at Exeter,

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: The mayor in courtesy show'd me the castle,

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: And call'd it Rougemont: at which name I started,

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Because a bard of Ireland told me once

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: I should not live long after I saw Richmond.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: My Lord!

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Ay, what's o'clock?

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: I am thus bold to put your grace in mind

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Of what you promised me.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Well, but what's o'clock?

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Upon the stroke of ten.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Well, let it strike.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Why let it strike?

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Because that, like a Jack, thou keep'st the stroke

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Betwixt thy begging and my meditation.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: I am not in the giving vein to-day.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Why, then resolve me whether you will or no.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Tut, tut,

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Thou troublest me; am not in the vein.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Exeunt all but BUCKINGHAM

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Is it even so? rewards he my true service

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: With such deep contempt made I him king for this?

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: O, let me think on Hastings, and be gone

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: To Brecknock, while my fearful head is on!

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Exit

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: SCENE III. The same.

speaker: BUCKINGHAM
text_entry: Enter TYRREL

speaker: TYRREL
text_entry: The tyrannous and bloody deed is done.

speaker: TYRREL
text_entry: The most arch of piteous massacre

speaker: TYRREL
text_entry: That ever yet this land was guilty of.

speaker: TYRREL
text_entry: Dighton and Forrest, whom I did suborn

speaker: TYRREL
text_entry: To do this ruthless piece of butchery,

speaker: TYRREL
text_entry: Although they were flesh'd villains, bloody dogs,

speaker: TYRREL
text_entry: Melting with tenderness and kind compassion

speaker: TYRREL
text_entry: Wept like two children in their deaths' sad stories.

speaker: TYRREL
text_entry: 'Lo, thus' quoth Dighton, 'lay those tender babes:'

speaker: TYRREL
text_entry: 'Thus, thus,' quoth Forrest, 'girdling one another

speaker: TYRREL
text_entry: Within their innocent alabaster arms:

speaker: TYRREL
text_entry: Their lips were four red roses on a stalk,

speaker: TYRREL
text_entry: Which in their summer beauty kiss'd each other.

speaker: TYRREL
text_entry: A book of prayers on their pillow lay;

speaker: TYRREL
text_entry: Which once,' quoth Forrest, 'almost changed my mind;

speaker: TYRREL
text_entry: But O! the devil'--there the villain stopp'd

speaker: TYRREL
text_entry: Whilst Dighton thus told on: 'We smothered

speaker: TYRREL
text_entry: The most replenished sweet work of nature,

speaker: TYRREL
text_entry: That from the prime creation e'er she framed.'

speaker: TYRREL
text_entry: Thus both are gone with conscience and remorse;

speaker: TYRREL
text_entry: They could not speak; and so I left them both,

speaker: TYRREL
text_entry: To bring this tidings to the bloody king.

speaker: TYRREL
text_entry: And here he comes.

speaker: TYRREL
text_entry: Enter KING RICHARD III

speaker: TYRREL
text_entry: All hail, my sovereign liege!

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Kind Tyrrel, am I happy in thy news?

speaker: TYRREL
text_entry: If to have done the thing you gave in charge

speaker: TYRREL
text_entry: Beget your happiness, be happy then,

speaker: TYRREL
text_entry: For it is done, my lord.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: But didst thou see them dead?

speaker: TYRREL
text_entry: I did, my lord.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: And buried, gentle Tyrrel?

speaker: TYRREL
text_entry: The chaplain of the Tower hath buried them;

speaker: TYRREL
text_entry: But how or in what place I do not know.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Come to me, Tyrrel, soon at after supper,

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: And thou shalt tell the process of their death.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Meantime, but think how I may do thee good,

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: And be inheritor of thy desire.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Farewell till soon.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Exit TYRREL

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: The son of Clarence have I pent up close;

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: His daughter meanly have I match'd in marriage;

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: The sons of Edward sleep in Abraham's bosom,

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: And Anne my wife hath bid the world good night.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Now, for I know the Breton Richmond aims

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: At young Elizabeth, my brother's daughter,

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: And, by that knot, looks proudly o'er the crown,

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: To her I go, a jolly thriving wooer.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Enter CATESBY

speaker: CATESBY
text_entry: My lord!

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Good news or bad, that thou comest in so bluntly?

speaker: CATESBY
text_entry: Bad news, my lord: Ely is fled to Richmond;

speaker: CATESBY
text_entry: And Buckingham, back'd with the hardy Welshmen,

speaker: CATESBY
text_entry: Is in the field, and still his power increaseth.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Ely with Richmond troubles me more near

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Than Buckingham and his rash-levied army.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Come, I have heard that fearful commenting

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Is leaden servitor to dull delay;

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Delay leads impotent and snail-paced beggary

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Then fiery expedition be my wing,

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Jove's Mercury, and herald for a king!

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Come, muster men: my counsel is my shield;

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: We must be brief when traitors brave the field.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: SCENE IV. Before the palace.

speaker: KING RICHARD III
text_entry: Enter QUEEN MARGARET

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: So, now prosperity begins to mellow

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And drop into the rotten mouth of death.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Here in these confines slily have I lurk'd,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: To watch the waning of mine adversaries.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: A dire induction am I witness to,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And will to France, hoping the consequence

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Will prove as bitter, black, and tragical.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Withdraw thee, wretched Margaret: who comes here?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Enter QUEEN ELIZABETH and the DUCHESS OF YORK

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Ah, my young princes! ah, my tender babes!

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: My unblown flowers, new-appearing sweets!

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: If yet your gentle souls fly in the air

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: And be not fix'd in doom perpetual,

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Hover about me with your airy wings

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: And hear your mother's lamentation!

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Hover about her; say, that right for right

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Hath dimm'd your infant morn to aged night.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: So many miseries have crazed my voice,

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: That my woe-wearied tongue is mute and dumb,

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Edward Plantagenet, why art thou dead?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Plantagenet doth quit Plantagenet.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Edward for Edward pays a dying debt.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Wilt thou, O God, fly from such gentle lambs,

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: And throw them in the entrails of the wolf?

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: When didst thou sleep when such a deed was done?

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: When holy Harry died, and my sweet son.

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Blind sight, dead life, poor mortal living ghost,

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Woe's scene, world's shame, grave's due by life usurp'd,

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Brief abstract and record of tedious days,

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Rest thy unrest on England's lawful earth,

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Sitting down

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: Unlawfully made drunk with innocents' blood!

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: O, that thou wouldst as well afford a grave

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: As thou canst yield a melancholy seat!

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Then would I hide my bones, not rest them here.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: O, who hath any cause to mourn but I?

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Sitting down by her

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: If ancient sorrow be most reverend,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Give mine the benefit of seniory,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And let my woes frown on the upper hand.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: If sorrow can admit society,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Sitting down with them

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Tell o'er your woes again by viewing mine:

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: I had an Edward, till a Richard kill'd him;

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: I had a Harry, till a Richard kill'd him:

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Thou hadst an Edward, till a Richard kill'd him;

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Thou hadst a Richard, till a Richard killed him;

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: I had a Richard too, and thou didst kill him;

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: I had a Rutland too, thou holp'st to kill him.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Thou hadst a Clarence too, and Richard kill'd him.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: From forth the kennel of thy womb hath crept

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: A hell-hound that doth hunt us all to death:

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: That dog, that had his teeth before his eyes,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: To worry lambs and lap their gentle blood,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: That foul defacer of God's handiwork,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: That excellent grand tyrant of the earth,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: That reigns in galled eyes of weeping souls,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Thy womb let loose, to chase us to our graves.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: O upright, just, and true-disposing God,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: How do I thank thee, that this carnal cur

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Preys on the issue of his mother's body,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And makes her pew-fellow with others' moan!

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: O Harry's wife, triumph not in my woes!

speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
text_entry: God witness with me, I have wept for thine.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Bear with me; I am hungry for revenge,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And now I cloy me with beholding it.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Thy Edward he is dead, that stabb'd my Edward:

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Thy other Edward dead, to quit my Edward;

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Young York he is but boot, because both they

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Match not the high perfection of my loss:

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Thy Clarence he is dead that kill'd my Edward;

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: And the beholders of this tragic play,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: The adulterate Hastings, Rivers, Vaughan, Grey,

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
text_entry: Untimely smother'd in their dusky graves.

speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
